(ṣemeṃts) (yä)
kt-āñmä , satāṣlñe ; kauc ka ṣ āṃtsne , musnānträ :

transcription.prose:
|| tumeṃ mahendrasene wa(lo) ///
ts(e)naṃ pilkosa yokamane ram no āñmalāṣṣälñesa ///
m· (a)mācäntäś weṣṣäṃ || strivighātne || palkas kärpye-saṃsār ce māka =mpe(le) ///

line.tr: ... brings (?) ... Having fixed his blue gaze upon the sick, he is sad with all his heart ... (and says: "...)

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

line.tr: ... this world is led! || in gautamakapil || Some look lethargic, the eyes cast down ... [1a]
... their heads [are] battered. [1b] Some are half covered with wounds, of some the bellies ...
... their skin ... [1d] The hearts of some are bounding and they are very harshly tormented. [2a] Others ...
Of some the exhalation is feeble, and they just shrug their shoulders. [2c] Others (have) a disease of the mouth and jaundice ...
miserable [with] tuberculosis, or with tumors. [3a] [Their] lips [are] parched with thirst, and they are bound only to their bed[s] because of sorrow ...
... some have become ... and reflect only anxiety. 3[d]" || Thereupon king Mahendrasena ...
... with his blue gaze drinking as it were out of pity ...
... he says to the ministers || in strivighāt ||: "See this low saṃsāra, [which is] very horrible! [1a] ...
... [1b] ... He exchanged their sorrowful appearances. [1c] Through the caläm of everyone's own deed ...

comments.comment: The first metrical section comprises three strophes in gautamakapil. This tune is known from Tocharian A, where it has 4 x 7 ¦ 7 syllables (; – not with 4 x 7 ¦ 7 ¦ 4 syllables). Also here an analysis with 4 x 7 ¦ 7 syllables seems the only possibility; apparently the strophe number 1 is lacking after yetse ceṃts : in line a4. raiweñ ṣemi lkānträ cai ¦ kätkri eśne /// [1a] (3 syllables missing) [a3] wlauwa aścī cets [1b] (9 syllables missing) pilentaccī ywārc no ksa ¦ ṣemeṃts katsāñ śa- /// [1c] (2 syllables missing) [a4] yetse ceṃts : [1d] (11 syllables missing) ṣemeṃts käryāñ pruknānträ ¦ räskre māka tsärkalyi : [2a] alyaik t· /// [2b] (12 syllables missing) (ṣemeṃts yä) [a5] kt-āñmä satāṣlñe ¦ kauc ka ṣ āṃtsne musnānträ : [2c] (2 syllables missing) som halimak alyeṅkäṃ(ts) ¦ /// [2d] (7 syllables missing) [b1] kṣai kurmaci tallāñco : [3a] (7 syllables missing) aswa lymine yokaisa ¦ tswoṣ ka ṣ läkleñ leki(ne) /// [3b] (1 syllable missing) – missing completely – [3c] (14 syllables missing) [b2] t ṣemi tatākaṣ ¦ alpanaṃ ka ṣ īwate 3 (2 syllables missing)

Of the second metrical section in strivighāt only the beginning is preserved. The metre is here a, c, d: 7 ¦ 4, b: 7 ¦ 7 (alternatively, strivighāt is also attested with a, c, d: 8 ¦ 3 or with b: 8 ¦ 8; see ). palkas kärpye-saṃsār ce ¦ māka =mpe(le) /// [1a] (1 syllable missing) [b5] l· – [1b] (12 syllables missing) – ceṃts myāska weṣanma ¦ läklessonta : [1c] (1 syllable missing) ṣñār yāmorntse calämtsa ¦ – /// [1d] (4 syllables missing)

On the basis of the metrical analysis of the three strophes in a2-b2, 12-17 syllables are missing on the right of each line. On the right of line a2 12 syllables are missing; on the right of line a3 13 syllables; on the right of line a4 14 syllables; on the right of line a5 14 syllables and the strophe number 2; on the right of line b1 17 syllables. Also the analysis of the fragmentary strophe in b4-5 suggests that 14 syllables are missing on the right of line b4. With an average of approximately 25 akṣaras preserved on each full line (i.e. except lines a3 and b3, which contain the string hole space), and an estimated average of 16 akṣaras missing, the original width of the leaf must have been approximately 37 cms.

According to , this is one of three manuscriprs mentioning King Mahendrasena (the other two being and ). He goes on to describe and this ms. as "five line manuscripts, written in the same large ductus, but probably not following. The state of preservation of both is very clear, but [this ms.] has been blackened appreciably, whereas [ ] is white." This ms. is a left hand edge.
llaṣṣäṃ: in spite of the abrasion, the reading seems secure. A restoration is difficult. Should the correct reading be ll[ā]_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ, then (kä)llāṣṣäṃ 'brings' could be restored.
som: according to to be identified as Skt. soma, "a disease of the mouth".
halimak: cf Skt. halīmaka, a kind of jaundice (), 'malignant jaundice' ().
kṣai: cf Skt. kṣaya, here as phthisis or phthisis pulmonalis (tuberculosis).
kurmaci: adj. derived from kurm or kwarm 'tumor' (Skt. gulma 'id.').
(a)mācäntäś: the reading is secure, but the correct form would be (a)mācäntaś, for amācäntaśc
: the lowest stroke of the 3 is abraded, but the reading is nevertheless certain.

strophe.pada: /// poyśiññai , ekṣalympa ; kamtsatai twe no ṣp :
tuk māka mā nai ; ttauwak te-yä(kne,sa) ///
ente krUi śpālme ; toṃ tarya nom,yentampa ; mā ke(kamu) ///
su krUi ra triśäṃ ; ot mā cwi n· ///
yolo yamaṣän no ; añmatse śle =lyeṅkäts ; ka ts(a) p(ä)st ///
/// ; (ra)mtä kāre,ne klāyä ; kwri auswa nno tsa 4
laṅkce slakareṃ ; ceṃ palsko ā,yātaicce ; kartseś pä

line.tr: ... to come together with the community in listening to the law and in ... [1b] All these obstacles ... [1c]

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 b1 b2 b3 b4

line.tr: ... and you have come together with the right time of an omniscient one. [1d] Those who lead to virtue ... [2a]
Mit der Wirkungszeit eines Allerkenners bist auch du zusammengekommen.
You also came together with the time of an Omniscient's ministry.
... you have the insight and the desire for virtue. [2b] That much [you] do not ... precisely this ... in this way ... [2c]
... 2[d] If he has not come together with the three excellent jewels [3a]
... he will be to be turned in ... [3c] Even if he makes a mistake than his ... is not ... [3d]
... [4a] He commits evil for himself and for others ... only away. [4b]
... like a ... if he falls in a pit, ... wearing ... 4[d] One should not trust an untrustworthy [person] ... [5a]
... [5b] This light and unsteady mind, untamable, ... (is led?) to virtue ... [5c]

comments.comment: The upper and lower margins of the fragment are preserved, and most probably the right margin in lines a1-2 and b3-4 as well. Approximately 1 akṣara is missing on the right of lines a3 and b2, and approximately 5 akṣaras are missing on the right of lines a4 and b1. According to the metre (which is not absolutely certain, see the discussion below), 19-21 syllables are missing on the left in the lines with the string hole space (apparently a2, a3, and b2), and 24-25 are missing in the other lines (a4, b1, b3, b4, and most probably also a1). Since lines a1, a2, b3, and b4 contain 19-21 akṣaras, and the 24-25 missing syllables on the left will make about 28 akṣaras, the original width of the leaf may have been close to 50 akṣaras or approximately 40 cms.
According to "[w]ritten in medium ductus, and clearly preserved".

sāṅkämpa ṣpä śamtsi: restored sāṅkämpa (ṣe) ṣpä śamtsi. Indeed, there is a hole of the size of approximately one akṣara after sāṅkämpa (not with sāṅkämpā!), but on the evidence of āyātaicce b4 no text is missing and the hole must have been there already at the time the manuscript was written. Although 'come together' is often "com. + eṣe + kəm-", it is here clearly just "com. + kəm-"; cf. ekṣalympa kamtsatai a2.
star-ca: for star-cä
nomyentampa: for naumyentampa.
śpālme: for śpālmeṃ. Pace , śpālme is not a variant, but simply a mistake.

mā ke(kamu): restored mā ke(kenusa), but the first akṣara cannot have e-vocalism according to the manuscript traces (also, his translation as 'attained' is not correct and does not fit his restoration). In addition, kekenu is always construed with a perl., i.e. 'provided with', whereas we have here a com. The construction com. + kekamu is also found in b2. One further syllable is required by the metre, but there is no reason to restore a nom.sg.f. kekamusa; rather, one might think of a particle like ṣpä or no.
spārtatsi tākaṃ: this construction is unclear and the meaning is obscure.

/// (ra)mtä kārene klāyä kwri auswa nno tsa: this passage is obscure. With , klāyä is probably to be corrected into klāyaṃ, but especially auswa nno tsa is difficult. In any case, 's reading kārene klāyaṃ kwri auswann ot sa "Wenn sie (?) in die Grube fällt, dann schreit (?) sie" is not convincing either.

āyātaicce: according to the context, the word seems complete, but there is a hole of the size of approximately one akṣara between ā and yātaicce that was presumably already there when the manuscript was written.
laṅkce slakareṃ ceṃ palsko āyātaicce: cf. Uv.31.8a-b spandanaṃ capalaṃ cittaṃ durakṣyaṃ durnivāraṇam () 'The mind that is trembling and unsteady, difficult to guard and difficult to restrain' ().

line.tr: ... she has come to us. ... not ... sorrow of the mind ...

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 a7 a8 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6 b7 b8

line.tr: ... we shall be zealous [so that] he who is going on the road of the antaradvīpa ...
... 1 || The yakṣa Agnikeśa says: || in the [tune] nauṣaññe-taruṇadi(vākarne ||)
... his compassion. He is confused by the delusion of their sorrows.
... with faith (/ compassion?) he says: || in the [tune] nauṣaññe-nāṭakäṣṣene || «Taste ...
... he blocks (/ fills up?) some mixtures/applications. In a harsh way you are holding him ...
... With a lovely gaze he drinks as it were that sorrow of theirs. ...
... his heart (?) ...
... so that (?) I go to see him [and] yo console [him] in his sorrow ...
... they cried out with loud voice and began to ...
... the king of ... is hit by a poisonous arrow in the heart. With a great roar ...
... very much. In separate ways you show [your] form like a parre. To be seen ...
... may I take [this] burden of sorrow of theirs. May I even stay ...
...beings (?). Noble wisdom, good forms [and] splendour. All ...
... he sent down into the human world. Virtuous ...

comments.comment: nauṣaññe taruṇadi(vākar) in line a3 will have the same metre as taruṇadivākar, that is a, b, d: 7 ¦ 7 ¦ 5 and c: 5 ¦ 5 (). Indeed, : ceṃts läklentaṣṣe trikau traikesa : in line a4 is 5 ¦ 5 and must therefore be pāda c.

a4: on the left, 4 akṣaras for vākar || are missing, and 34 more syllables according to the metre. Thus, approximately 40 akṣaras are in total missing on the left. Probably, the string hole space covered this line, so that in lines 1-3 and 6-8 even more akṣaras may be missing.
According to "[w]ritten in very large ductus, and clearly preserved, it is the right edge of an eight line manuscript."
(takarṣ)käññesa, (añmālaṣ)käññesa
raitwenta, pwenta
naitwe: temple, mud?? NO: nai twe
cf. b3 ts(e)naṃ pilkosa yokamane ram no āñmalāṣṣälñesa – ///
mā = māka 'very'/ māntsatsi 'be sad'?
parre: probably a mistake for prere 'arrow' (see preresa b3).

line.tr: ... he sees the spirit, which is not bound by (...) things, as the cause to the redemption of the sorrows, [and] he sees [it] as the way to the nirvāṇa. In this way the ... of the filth ...

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6

line.tr: ... (being) arising through causes; he sees them extinguishing in the non-existence of the causes, without substance [and] empty. Thereupon the whole world ... step (by step)
... looking after (= anupaśya) is the basis of consciousness (= smṛtyupasthāna). Looking after the law among the laws [is done] by the basis of consciousness. The four noble (truths?) ...
... the eightfold noble path, leading to the suppression of sorrow, is the truth of the noble ones. || || This is the second pratīsamutpāda.
... The rūpaskandha is to be looked at in this way: [it is] like an ant hill (lit. 'ant nest'). As the ants enter into [their] hill, so the rūpaskandha ...
... pricks, sorrow through ... here the nature of ignorance is to be observed. || If the skandha of sense (= vedānāskandha) pricked, ...

... [and] with one hand he drew this poisoned arrow (i.e., the vedānāskandha) out of it, [and] with the other (lit. second) hand he smeared medicine on it and made him quiet – this then is immeasurable sorrow.
Mit der (einen) Hand möge er ihm diesen Pfeil ... herausziehen, mit der anderen Hand möge er ihm Heilmittel aufschmieren [und] ihn zur Ruhe bringen.
With (one) hand he shall pull the arrow out of him ...., with the other hand he shall smear medicine on him [and] get him to rest.
... Like the light of the moon and the stars in a large lake on a dark night: as often as one touches in the water in order to seize it, so often one sees (that it is an illusion).
[Just] as the light of the moon and the stars in a large lake on a dark night: as often as one touches in the water in order to seize it, so often one sees (that it is an illusion).
... Like if a blind man wove a garment [and], being helplessly thrown, it burnt in the homely (lit. maternal) hearth,
... (just like that) ... burn in the hearth of impermanence. He sees even the exertions as empty and as deceit. He sees perception (= vijñāna) as something volatile, glowing now here then there ...
... Thus I have pervaded divine and human forms in this string of deed[s], thus [also] hell, animal and preta [forms]. Just as one sees one's own cycle of form[s], ...
... I made rain the down-pour of sense (= vedānā) for myself and for others. || The sign [is] the attachment like [to] a heap of jewels ... the four ornaments ...

comments.comment: b3-6 have a parallel in a1-6;
"Written in small ductus, and very clearly preserved, it is the right edge, and probably half, of a large ... manuscript" ().
snai-āñm: literally 'without self', here 'without substance' after
omṣostäṃ: for ompostäṃ
first palkalyñe: pa added under line
wete: for wate.
rūpaṣṣe ātse: lit. 'the shoulder of the rūpa', where ātse (for āntse is a literal rendering of Skt. skandha 'shoulder; skandha (an element)'.
warpalyñaṣṣe: for warpalyñeṣṣe.
eṅwe for eṅkwe.
nāskoy: argues for 'spin', but 'weave', also attested for the TA equivalent of this verb, fits definitely better here.
enersäṅk: if Malzahn's 'hilflos' () is correct, it must refer to the garment, which seems to be the subject of the following clause.

after a1, we can complete from approximately the 12th akṣara of this line onwards koy w· or koy l·. This may be a further optative, e.g. tākoy '[if] he were'. Unfortunately, this fragmentary restoration is followed by a considerable lacuna of unknown length.
nrai: with , the akṣara looks rather like trai.
after a3, the left part of this line must have contained ssont • || saṃsāräntse svabhāpsa ().
ṣotri eṅkalyñe: this expression returns in b5.

internalComments.comment: If the form trikṣaiṃ is to be read as an adjective, then it might give us an idea about the etymology of yolo. It clearly is built from a present stem of an "antigrundverb". So yolo might equally be a formation from a present stem, maybe one that inflects like yok- "drink". The only problem with this would be the lack of palatalization.

The translation is wrong. śrigupti is not "BHS" śrīgupti, but the genitive of the personal name śrigupte. In the Tibetan canon, the Jain Śrīgupta invited the Buddha to a meal in order to kill him. The Buddha resisted all of his attempts. In the end, Śrīgupta is ashamed, apologizes and takes refuge in Buddhism. Thus, we should translate: "The evil dead done to you by Śrīgupta disappeared through (his taking) refuge in you." Besides the Tibetan canon, we also have a Chinese translation by Narendrayaśas (德 護 長 者 經 , Taishō 545). It seems that this story was also popular in the Tarim Basin. https://eprints.soas.ac.uk/23139/1/toh217_84000-srigupta-sutra.pdf
"The king of Māgadha" refers to Ajātaśatru.

pada.s:
I have not been able to satiate [this] ocean of the sense[s]; (i)
ntriṣṣe , samuddär ; mā soyässi , cämyāwa ;
[that] is my fault. nesañ nāki :
On the path of [my] own deed[s] [my] relatives have gone separated from me, ṣañ yāmorṣṣai , ytārisa ; waiptār maiytar-ñ , cai ṣñaṣṣi ;
they have forgotten me. ñiś märsāre :

Alone I expel (evil). ṣesk(e) (yolo) ,
lyutaskau ;
May there be shame on me for the attempt of [any] evil [deed]. po yolainäts , smāntsa ñiś ; kwīpe tākoy
O lord, o omniscient, o compassionate one! O [you] who let go all offences of the erring beings! saswa poyśi , =ñmālaṣka ; po träṅkonta , tärkaucai ; trikṣaiṃ wnolmets :

Towards you again I stretch the palms [of my hands]. ciś yak raksau , a(lyi)
ne ;
Be a spokesman for me before the beings! weñmo ptākañ ,onolmeṃ(ts) ;
May they let go my offence! (tä)rko-ñ traṅko :
I see my fault. nāki lkāskau ,
I turn away from evil because of this in all births. klautkomar ; yolaiñemeṃ , tesa mant ; po cmelane :

And may I permamently enjoy the fruit for their sake even on the Avīci earth. awiśäṣṣai , kentsa ka
ṣpä ; śāśwat oko , warpoymar ; ce(ṃ)ts pakāna :
[While my] vessels are burnt by the fires of remorse, I dwell like an empty tree [12a] with glowing spirit, onmiṣṣana , pwārasa ; tsäksemane , marmanma ; troṅktse stām ra :

sälpi-ñ cittsa , wo
lokmar ,
[and] I press my vessels day and night. nuskaskemar ; marmanma , iṅkauṃ kästwer :
Would the flames of hell drag me with this human body into the Avīci hell? tā ka ṣpä śāmñai , kektseñtsa ; nraiṣṣi sl(e)mi , pannoṃ ñiś ; eṃṣky āwiśne :

But may my mind be satiated with terrible passions; empelona , kleśanma ;
mai no pals(k)o , soyi pästä ;
may it be completely under control! sañāt tākoy
O compassionate one, o pitying one, I shelter with you, karuṇīka , =ñmālaṣ(k)a ; (t)auko(-c)
I call on you with a wish and with confidence. kwāmar(-c) , akālksa ; pk(w)alñemp= eṣe :
Smashed on the head by passions, I [have] certainly given up this terrible self. āś papyāku , kleśanmats ; a(t)ts(ai)k ṣ(a)ñ āñm , r(e)r(i)nu ; ñiś empele
Fill up the hollow of compassion! karuṇaṣṣe , tr(o)ṅk prutk(a)r ;

Therein I will hide, in your protection, father, so that my fear will rest!
tune taukau-c , saim pācer ; lāma-ñ prosko
Not even once in the births have I got to hear [this] name, mā ṣṣe nta kca , cmelane ; ñem ra klyaussi , kälpāwa ;
and therefore afterwards, [14a] lacking a good teacher, I have not once stood back because of evil. twār ṣä postaññe

krentä käṣṣintsa , meṅkitse ;
yolaiñesa , mā ṣṣe nta ; aṣkār śmāwa :
With the fires of shame and repentence I burn the base of life kwīpe-onmiṣṣeṃ , pwārasa ; tsaksau śmoññai , śaulaṣṣai ;
and it does not block me [anymore]. mā ṣ prutkaṣä-ñ :
I fall onto your protection. ciṣṣe saimäś , kloyomar ;

May my deed disappear! nau
yto-ñ yāmor ,
May it be wiped out! kāntoytär-ñ ;
May there be forgiveness for me! kṣ(ān)t(i) tākoy-ñä
Who has taken excellent protection in you, his bad deed disappeared through your protection. cine yāmu , śrigupti ; yolo yāmor , nautā-ne ; ciṣṣek saimtsa :

The king of Magadha, incited by evil friends, killed his good father. walo māga,(tṣe)
yolaiṃ ; wāṣmots ṣeṣar,tu kausa ; pātär krent
At your feet he made effort, tañ paiynene , spalkāte ;
recognised (lit. thought) [his] fault nāki palyka ,
[and] [keeping away] from evil he obtained purity. yolomeṃ ; kalp= āstarñe :

Comparable to that I tell my own sorrow too – tu menāksa , ñiś rano ; lakl= a(ñma)
ntse , ñiś weskau ;
may there be forgiveness for me! deśit tākoy-ñä
May there be a deed of threefold virtue for me in the saṃsāra without beginning. snai yparwecce , saṃsārne ; täryā-yäkne , kärtseṣṣe ; yāmor tākoy-ñä :
alyek yey(mä) , a

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6

line.tr: Ich kehre um von der Schlechtigkeit hierdurch in allen Geburten.
I turn away from wickedness therefore, in all incarnations.
Während die Adern von den Feuern der Reue verbrannt werden, weile ich wie ein ausgehöhlter Baum mit glühendem Geist [und] drücke [meine] Adern bei Tag [und] Nacht.
While [my] veins are burned by the fires of remorse, I tarry like a hollowed tree with a glowing spirit [and] press my veins by day [and] night.
Would the flames of hell drag me with this human body into the Avīci hell? But may my mind be satiated with terrible passions;457 may it be completely under control!
O Barmherziger, Mitleidiger! Ich schreie [und] rufe dich in dem Wunsch voll von Vertrauen.
Oh compassionate one, oh pitying one, I cry [and] call you with [my] wish and full of trust.
Fill up the hollow of compassion! Therein I will hide, in your protection, father, so that my fear will rest! (cf 322–323, 328)
Mit den Feuern von Reue [und] Scham verbrenne ich die Lebensgrundlage, und nicht umschließt sie(?) mich mehr.
With the fire of remorse [and] shame I burn the foundation of life and it(?) does not cling about me anymore.
Möge das Karman mir schwinden [und] von mir abgerieben werden!
May my karma disappear [and] be rubbed off me!
Von schlechten Freunden aufgestachelt, tötete der König (von) Magadha [seinen] guten Vater. Zu deinen Füßen bemühte er sich, sah den Fehler ein [und] erlangte vom Bösen Reinigung.
Incited by wicked friends, the king (of) Magadha killed [his] god father. At your feet he exerted himself, saw the error [and] obtained cleansing of evil.
15[d] [16a] To another I (?) went ...

comments.comment: on line number: one stroke can be seen; it could also be ‘2’ or ‘3’

Although virāma is in many cases correctly written in this manuscript, it is lacking in a number of cases where it is required by the metre: ṣpä a4, a5 read ṣp; pästä a6 read päst; ṣä b2 read ṣ; krentä b2 read krent; tākoy-ñä b4, b6 read tākoy-ñ. Also kwīpe-onmiṣṣeṃ b3 has to be read as kwīp=-onmiṣṣeṃ.

In several cases metrical sandhi is already written in the manuscript: poyśi =ñmālaṣka a2 for poyśi añmālaṣka; karuṇīka =ñmālaṣ(k)a (because of the metre it cannot be karuṇīk= añmālaṣ(k)a, pace , ) a6 for karuṇīka añmālaṣ(k)a; pk(w)alñemp= eṣe a6 for pk(w)alñempa eṣe, kalp= āstarñe b5 for kalpa astarñe; lakl= a(ñma)ntse b5-6 for lakle a(ñma)ntse. The narrative part of strophe 15 contains two metrical irregularities: walo māga(tṣe) yolaiṃ b4-5 with 5+2 syllables instead 4+3 (the restoration to māga(tṣe) seems nevertheless correct); and likewise wāṣmots ṣeṣartu kausa with 5+2 syllables instead 4+3.

According to "[t]he manuscript consists of two parts ... A.30 is the left portion and ... A.26 forms the right part ... [w]ritten in medium ductus, it is very clearly preserved."
yāmorṣṣai: a little piece of paper covers the place where the vowel sign of rṣṣai should be, but slight traces of both ai-strokes are still discernible.
=ñmālaṣka: ṣka is added under the line; the addition is marked with a cross above.

smāntsa: the translation of smāṃ follows , who proposes 'test' as the basic meaning. However, his discussion of this passage () is not completely satisfactory: he translates 'try', which does not fit well. Further, it is peculiar that the word is preceded by po yolainäts (pace Ogihara l.c., not po yolainats): obviously, the attempt of any single evil deed will already be a shame. Further, his translations of the prs. lyutaskau as 'I shall drive away', and of the opt. tākoy as 'will be' are in my view not correct.
nauyto-ñ: for nautoy-ñ.

Pages also reversed in , who describes the ms. as "[w]ritten in medium ductus ... badly abraded and to all intents and purposes illegible on verso".

line.tr: ... is to be brought ... ; not in a place where water is released; not ...
... it is (not) to be scoured (?) with sand and dung. It is not to be put on excrement (?).
... it is (not) to be put on ... too long. It is not to be broken intentionally.
.. it is (not) to be ... It is to be guarded carefully. • You are not to seek another alms bowl yourself.
... if you have ..., it is to be given up in the community. This ...
/// (ṣa)māne yayāṣṣoṣ ñare sarki • alecce wāpa
/// – aleccemeṃ ñare sarki yāṣträ duṣkṛta alecce
/// (wa)t(kä)ṣṣäṃ niḥsargika-pātayantika 70 jñātikenmeṃ ñare sarki
/// (ma trä)ṅko alecce wāpatsi watkäṣṣäṃ niḥsargika-pātayantika
/// -ṣṣä(ṃ) jñātikeṃ wāpatsi watkäṣṣäṃ|watkaṣäṃ, [he has] no offence.
/// (jñā)tikeṃ wāpatsi watkäṣṣäṃ|watka, [he is] without offence. ||

comments.comment: The spelling llya for the nom.sg.f. ending of the gerund for usual lya is striking, but need to reflect anything in real speech. Should it stand for some speech-real phenomenon, then it would obviously be a palatalisated geminate /ĺĺ/.

Upper, lower, and right margins preserved. Pace , is probably right that the string hole space is preserved in lines a4 and b3, and probably also in a3 and b4. Thus the leaf may have been relatively small, i.e. not wider than approximately 15 cms.
describes the ms as "[w]ritten in medium ductus, and clearly preserved, but the manuscript is blackened both sides, worse on the verso".
īkene: the first akṣara is probably to be read as ī, not i (pace ; ).

(ma wara)ñcäcce meltesa käccillya: the restoration of this clause is difficult. Following and , restores (śi)ñcäcce meltesa käccillya and translates "/// it should not be put down on the on snow-covered dung.". This expression is not found in the Chinese parallel that he adduces. However, he underlines "You should not wash it with the sand and the dung.", his translation of 不應以雜沙牛屎洗。, meaning that this passage is also found in the Tocharian B text (cf also "Der Mönch [...] muß ermahnt werden, [...] sie nicht mit Sand oder Kuhurin zu reinigen"). As far as I can see, it is not necessary to restore /// ñcäcce as (śi)ñcäcce: many more words in -ñce could form an adjective in -tstse. One of these is warañce 'sand', which seems to fit the context better: 以雜沙牛屎 'with a mix of sand and cow dung' may have been warañcäcce meltesa, literally 'with sandy cow dung', in Tocharian B. The next problem is the verb kətt- or kətk-, traditionally 'put down' (; ), but in fact the passages hardly allow us to establish its meaning. On the basis of the passage under discussion, one would rather expect something like 'wash, scour', which fits käccīyeṃ-ne b5 perfectly: 'Two (hell guards) scoured his body with gravel'. käccītär b5 is more difficult to interpret. It is clearly a bad wish to an honourable person by a jealous person. Perhaps 'he should be scoured together with this or that one' is also a possibility there.
s·: pace , who reads ·[s]·, the s is not uncertain and it is not lowered.

läntsa: for this hapax legomenon, plausibly suggests the meaning 'excrement', based on the assumption that the word is borrowed from Skt. laṇḍa 'excrement'. A minor point is that we would rather expect lānt, i.e. /lant/, not /lənt/.
mäkte: seems to stand for makte 'self', not for mäkte 'how, so' (pace ; not translated by ).
rī(talle): restores rī(tatar), which is grammatically also possible.
tākañca: for tākañc, i.e. tākaṃ-c.
/// -māne yayāṣṣoṣ: some of these akṣaras are damaged, but the reading is certain, pace , who reads /// (ṣa)[mān]e ya[yā]ṣṣoṣ (followed by ).
reads the first damaged akṣara as [60].
yāṣt_r_a: this is the correct reading (), pace , who reads yaṣt_r_a (followed by ).
watka: a mistake for watkäṣṣäṃ ().

line.tr: ... From there on they begin to recite the laws beginning with giving, moral behaviour and meditation.
... But he had a son [and] so was attached with pride. [With] brandy, in dancing [and] play [and] somedbody else's wives and so on ... [he spent his time] ...
... the son of ..., committing negligences in this way, did not act according to the word of his parents. Then king ...
... they ... him, made on his atāne (?) and threw him into prison. || ... of the householder ...
... and ... the the prince of the throne. || Thereupon ...
... by entering and so on, all property ...
... in offence ...
... who was prince ..., he is now ...
... will be bad. Thereupon all ...
... in twelve years ... with the mind ... afterwards [he] went (?) ...
... he was repentant [and] became zealous in giving. ... all evils ...
... zeigte Reue [und] war eifrig im Gabe[geben].
... showed remorse [and] was diligent in [giving] gifts.
... he is redeemed from [his] sorrows. Giving gift[s] in such a way, a being (may ward off ?) evil through the power of giving.
... love arises for him. He remembers all beings. Through his desire for their good he gives gift[s].
... in the ... part the second division has ended. || This division has written Śtweruṃ –. ||

comments.comment: This seems to be an abbreviated story as found e.g. in the Udl. Not a real jātaka.
According to "[w]ritten in medium ductus, and very clearly preserved it is the right and greater portion of a large eight line manuscript". also identifies this fragment as folios 15-16.
"||": rest of line empty.
r/v reversed on idp
Small ductus, very clearly preserved, left hand edge, probably 6 lines, schnurloch visible ().
"tūsa": "sa" added below line, 'x'mark above.
"–": a little piece that is wrongly attached here is not considered.

(k)iñ(c)i(t) kU(s)e cek warñai • sādhu lau(kikam) ///

comments.comment: Since this is a word-by-word bilingual, a full translation does not make much sense. Therefore, the full strophes of the Sanskrit text are cited below, and the problematic Tocharian correspondences are commented.
According to "[w]ritten in medium ductus, and clearly preserved, it is the left edge of a manuscript with six lines."

Cf. PPU 33 upaghātāvaraṇavan mitakālaṃ pradeśi ca | sulabhātiśayaṃ sarvam upamāvastu laukikam || 'Every worldly material for comparison is subject to injury and obscuration, limited in time and place, attained very easily.' ().
m(enāk): beginning of the translation of upamāvastu.

(ne)sallonaṃtso: this is the only possible restoration, but it is not the expected translation of agamyānām 'to the unapproachable [virtues]'. Probably, nes- 'be' is here used with a preceding element as a phrasal verb of the type peri nes- 'owe' (see ) and yumāne nes- 'perceive' (). Obviously, the negation mā will have preceded this element.

Cf. PPU 34 advaṃdvinām agamyānāṃ dhruvāṇām anivartinām | anuttarāṇāṃ kā tarhi guṇānām upamāstu te || 'What likeness indeed could there be to your virtues, unrivalled, unapproachable, lasting, turning not aside, unsurpassed?' ().
(tpa)rṣkäṃñene: 'in shallowness', so to be restored, with a.o. (pace ; ).

Cf. PPU 35 goṣpadottānatāṃ yāti gāmbhīryaṃ lavaṇāmbhasaḥ | yadā te buddhigāmbhīryam agādhāpāram īkṣyate || 'The depth of the salt ocean becomes shallow as a puddle when the unfathomable, boundless depth of your wisdom is beheld.' ().

(śiriṣäṣṣ)epi pit(ts)aunt(s)e: 'of a (śirīṣa) filament'; pace , the reading of is most probably correct. reads (śiri)ṣäṣṣe(p)i pint(s)aunt(s)e, which is defendable as far as pint(s)aunt(s)e is concerned, but of the first word really at most (śiriṣä)ṣ(ṣ)epi can be read (the p is much more certain than the ṣ). suggests āke (ake may be a typographical error) 'tip, end' as the correspondence of agra, which is also likely.

Cf. PPU 36 śirīṣapakṣmāgralaghu sthairyaṃ bhavati pārthivam | akampye sarvadharmāṇām tvatsthairye 'bhimukhīkṛte || 'The firm weight of the earth becomes light as the tip of a śirīṣa filament when compared with your firmness which nothing in nature can shake.' ().
(aknātsaññe)ṣṣe orkamñe kauṣeñc(antse): translates ajñānatimiraghnasya.

Cf. PPU 37 ajñānatimiraghnasya jñānālokasya te mune | na ravir viṣaye bhūmiṃ khādyotīm api vindati || 'Before the light of your knowledge, O Sage, which destroys the darkness of ignorance, the sun does not even attain the level of a firefly.' ().

ne ka ke: with , this must be the translation of viṣaye bhūmiṃ, and ke must therefore be corrected into keṃ 'earth'. However, his suggestion to restore the preceding ne ka to (viṣay)neka remains uncertain. Most probably, ne is the locative ending of a word translating viṣaya, while ka is the emphasising particle, meaning 'just, even'.
känmaskeṃ: translates āyānti. The Skt. preverb ā may have been explicitly rendered with TB ecce, as suggested by .

Cf. PPU 38 malinatvam ivāyānti śaraccandrāmbarāmbhasām | tava vāgbuddhiceṣṭānāṃ śuddhiṃ prati viśuddhayaḥ || 'The purity of moon, sky, and water in autumn become as if sullied when set against the purity of your words, mind, and actions.' ().

(kektse)ñäṣṣanaṃts: translates ceṣṭānāṃ. is not explicit, but he seems to assume that ñäṣṣanaṃts is a complete word. In my view, this cannot be the case. The root ñäsk- 'wish' does not fit semantically and no derivation of this kind is possible. Rather, -ṣṣanaṃts is the gen.pl.f. of a ṣṣe-adjective derived from kektseñe 'body', usually the first member of the standard expression kektseñ reki palskosa 'with body, word and mind'; cf. in particular the adjective a2 kektseñ-reki-pälskoṣṣe.
asta(räññe): translates śuddhiṃ. With , the following prati may have been rendered by etsuwai.

Cf. PPU 39 anena sarvaṃ vyākhyātaṃ yat kiṃcit sādhu laukikam | dūre hi buddhadharmāṇāṃ lokadharmās tapasvinaḥ || 'In naming these I have named every worldly good; for the paltry elements of the world are far removed from the elements of the Buddha.' ().
k_u(s)e cek warñai: translates the preceding (k)iñ(c)i(t). The punctuation mark "•" is missing because its function is taken over by the virāma dot: (k)i[ñ](c)i(_t)\•.

He washes their heads [for them].

comments.comment: According to "[w]ritten in medium ductus, and clearly preserved, it is the left edge of a five line manuscript, with the number '13' on the verso." He also identifies the fragment as folios 9-10 (op.cit.).
According to "[w]ritten in large ductus, and very clearly preserved, the fragment belongs to a manuscript with originally at least five lines"; recto and verso are reversed in op.cit.

According to , this is one of three manuscriprs mentioning King Mahendrasena (the other two being and ). He goes on to describe and this ms. as "five line manuscripts, written in the same large ductus, but probably not following. The state of preservation of both is very clear, but [ ] has been blackened appreciably, whereas [this ms.] is white." Cf. also ibid: 144: "the right hand edge of a five line manuscript ... The verso has only one line."

line.tr: /// is (not) any hindrance. The novice should be held under control by the monks, at first by the community.

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

line.tr: /// if he (does not) turn (away), the monk who knows (it), this (novice) in that way
Which monk, being aware of it, … in this manner …
/// who (gives) to this novice a support or again a dwelling place
/// (takes) off the jewels beginning with the gold and the silver by his own hand

(Which monk takes) up with his own hand valuables [lit. jewels] such as gold and silver, (or lets it take up, except when they are found within the boundary [of the monastery] or within [his] dwelling—pātayantika). If it is within the boundary [of the monastery], or within [his] (dwelling, he may take it up or have it taken up, thinking), «whose it may be, he will take it back», [he is] without offence. 8
/// [it should be taken off.] If it is inside the limit, or inside (the cell)
/// he asks, 'the one to whom it is own, he will carry it away'.
Der Eigentümer [wtl. wem es zu eigen ist, der] wird es [ab]holen.
The owner [lit. who[ever] it belongs to, he] will come for it.
/// if (a monk) makes for himself [=takes] (clothes), the proper (colour) should be done with any one of three proper (materials)
/// If a monk makes for himself clothes that have not been made proper
/// Within a half month, a monk should bathe a single time. If a monk
/// commits Pāt.-sin. There (is) the following opportunity. He is sick

comments.comment: According to , "[w]ritten in small ductus, and slightly abraded both recto and verso, it is the right edge of a five line manuscript".

line.tr: I will let rain a rain of weapons on the earth, and with a flood of weapons I will fill the cardinal directions. (cf 246; 325)
There is no one in this world who could have brought me into this misfortune by [his] power.
Die Pfeile eines Rachsüchtigen(?) haben mich heftig (ins Herz) getroffen.
The arrows of a vengeful(?) one have struck (my heart) violently.
For now I will perish with the root. (cf 326)

line.tr: If he doesn't control the mind, then he will receive the fruit like that.
[Wenn] einer sein Denken nicht beherrscht, so genießt er dies [als] Frucht [davon].
If someone does not restrain his thoughts, he enjoys this [as] fruit [thereof].
... das Denken wurde alsdann dem Elenden verwirrt.
... then the thought of the miserable one was confused [in] him.
Jetzt erduldet er äußerst schreckliches Leid.
Now he endures extremely terrible suffering.

line.tr: Her spirit was directed upon the one named [so-and-so]. 33. Thereupon I, O God, [have] another wish besides this one.
Through having heard these ślokas. He revealed a smile [and] spoke thus.
... er offenbarte ein Lächeln.
... he [let] show a smile.
The thirty three [gods] ... I ... fastened ... You, O Buddha!
Ordering the latter, the king of the gods came near, the god ...
When you offer the oath [of reverence] to the buddha [then] speak thus! 38. The king of gods has [descended onto] the world of the thirty three.
He reveres you. He asks you if [your] body [is] without ... disease, [and] has the wish to see the Buddha.
The thirty three [gods] and other gods and men desirous of happiness [and good fortune], with ...
Having heard from the Buddha, Pañcaśikha left the cave [and] came to Indra.
Be without concern! [This is] the twelfth act in the [play] 'The interrogation of Indra'.

line.tr: I, B., betake myself to the Lord Buddha.
I betake myself to the law of the Lord Buddha.
I betake myself to the monk(s). 3 (times to repeat)
I (now) have betaken myself to the Lord Buddha / to the law of the Lord Buddha / to the monk(s).
Henceforth (lit.: today (and) later) I long to watch suitably the eight good commandments ordered by the Lord Buddha; may I watch (them) completely. 3 (times to repeat)
Just as a monk, who has attained the blessed stage [...]
Listen, venerable Sir. Today (is) prāvaraṇā, held on the fifteenth (day), for the assembly. For me too today is prāvaraṇā, held on the fifteenth. I,
the monk nn, invite, Sir, the assembly (to instruct me) at the prepared place according to what was seen, heard or suspected. May the assembly instruct me out of mercy.
Knowing (and) seeing (my) sin, I shall expiate (it) according to the rule. ...
This book [belongs to? Or: was written by/is titled?] Kalyāṇa[...]
aṃ a, homage to the omniscient, to [...], whose knowledge is unstained [...]
... refuge may I become; the Lord Buddha Maitreya ...

comments.comment: The recto is in Turkic, but not according to the normal spelling conventions for brāhmī. Line b7 is in Turkic, too, whereas line b5 is in Tocharian B. Although all margins are torn, at least the Turkic text on the recto is continuous – it was clearly written after the leaf was torn. Lines b1-b4 are written in a rather small hand, lines b5-6 in a rather large one, line b7 in between. Transliterations and transcriptions follow Maue ().
"säkkez": for "säkkiz"
-yu_r\miśśe\: certainly for miśś\•; the virāma dot was mistakenly written as an "e" vowel mark.
"bitigen": for "bitigin"
"yönörmeṃ": for "yölönörmän"

... may be stopped ...
... Then king Hariścandra ... again ...
... (then) Indra (let) again (appear) a (group?) of brahmins ...
... (the brahmins) are standing miserable ... begging ...

comments.comment: In view of the space above line a1 and under line b4, it would seem that these are indeed the first and the last line of the leaf and the upper margin of the recto (lower of the verso) is preserved. In any case, no line is missing between a4 and b1, so that the manuscript probably had 4 lines on each side. On IDP, recto and verso are reversed.

According to "[w]ritten in medium ductus, and very clearly preserved, it is the middle of a manuscript of which only four lines remain visible". Broomhead gives the size as 3.5" in width and 2" in depth/height and has recto/verso inverted.
Uv.27.8c ahaṃ karomīti na tasya hiṃsyāt (for hiṃsyāt one should read hi syāt).
The marginal rests are difficult to interpret. m·sk· is here tentatively completed as (ya)m(a)sk(au), for karomi Uv. 27.8c.
Uv.27.9a-b mānopeto hy ayaṃ loko mānasaktaḥ sadā sthitaḥ
Uv.27.10a yat prāptaṃ yac ca prāptavyaṃ
Uv.27.10d jahyād vidvāṃ samāhitaḥ
kakraupau pa –: we expect kakraupau 10.
Uv.27.11c upasthānarataye ca (for °rataye one should read °ratā ye)
Uv.27.12b na doṣas teṣu vidyate
Uv.27.13b tv atilīyanti bāliśaḥ, here apparently atilīyati (no trace of an anusvāra over the ya can be discerned). The sg. atilīyati matches the otherwise irregular sg. bāliśaḥ ( III: 254a).
Uv.27.13d cakṣuṣmāṃs tāṃ prapaśyati

This is probably the beginning of the narrative passage about the snake, continued in a1–6 ().

comments.comment: The restoration to "(king) Subhāṣitagaveṣin" by Broomhead is probably wrong. Very probably not a narrative.
According to "[w]ritten in small ductus, and clearly preserved, it is from the middle of a five line manuscript".

It is possible that line a3 and a4 and line b1 and b2 reach all the way to the right margin of the manuscript (otherwise we are at the schnurloch space there). In line a3, [y]olo can be read if the folded piece at the verso is considered. The folded piece from the recto hides Broomheads śi at the beginning of line b2; a small piece lying on the manuscript hides the s of Broomheads k_use in line b4.
According to "[w]ritten in large ductus it is clearly preserved and appears to be the left hand edge of a four line manuscript".

comments.comment: The size of the lacuna between the left hand fragment and the right hand fragment IOL Toch 122 may be estimated between 7 and 14 akṣaras on the basis of the following speculative restorations (for several correspondences there are more possibilities, which are not noted here):

The difference between 7 akṣ. for lines a3/b3 and 10-14 akṣ. for lines a1-2/b4-5 suggests that a3/b3 contained the string hole space. On the basis of IOL Toch 122 b2, which preserves 7 full akṣaras on 6,4 cms, the size of a lacuna of 11-12 akṣaras may have been approximately 10 cms.

This fragment (IOL Toch 122, right) is from the same leaf as , left: IOL Toch 772 a1-3 and IOL Toch 772 b3-5 precede IOL Toch 122 a1-3 and IOL Toch 122 b3-5 by approximately 7 to 14 akṣ. or 10 cms (see the philological commentary for details). Traces of lines a5 and b1, which contained Uv.12.10c-11d, can be discerned. If the string hole space covered only a3/b3, the manuscript must originally have had 5 lines.
Uv.12.8b-c prajñayā paśyate yadā | atha nirvidyate duḥkhād
(pra)jñayā (paśyate yadā aiśamñesa lkāṣṣäṃ krui atha) nirvidyate = 14 akṣ.
Uv.12.8d-9a eṣa mārgo viśuddhaye // 8 ākhyāto vo mayā mārgaḥ
ā(khyāto vo mayā mārgaḥ ākṣu)sa = 10 akṣ.
Uv.12.9c-d yuṣmābhir eva karaṇīyam ākhyātāras tathāgatāḥ
(ka)ra(ṇīyam yessa yama)ṣṣälle = 7 akṣ.
Uv.12.10b tṛṣṇāśalyanikṛntanaḥ; all manuscripts used by , including this one, read °nikṛndana°
Uv.12.12a eṣo ’ñjaso hy eṣa ca vai parākramas
Uv.12.12b-c tv ekāyano haṃsapatho yathā hrade | yam adhyagāc chākyamuniḥ samāhitas
mäkt(e yolmeścä • yam adhya)gāc = 7 akṣ.
Uv.12.12d-13a tam eva cākhyāti gaṇeṣv abhīkṣṇaśaḥ || 12 ekāyanaṃ jātijarāntadarśī
gaṇ(eṣv abhīkṣṇaśaḥ tāu ṣpä aksaṣṣäṃ kraupe)nne = 12 akṣ.
Uv.12.13a-b ekāyanaṃ jātijarāntadarśī mārgaṃ vadaty eṣa hitānukampī
mā(rgaṃ vadaty eṣa hitānukampī ytā)ri = 11 akṣ.

line.tr: he does the connection involving sexual pleasure, step by step, concerning all (the cases), Sthūlātyaya. || Buddha was staying in Rājagṛha. A monk named Dhanika
Ein Mönch, Dhanika [mit] Namen, holte sich ohne Erlaubnis des Königs Ajātaśatru [wtl. ohne von König A. mit einer Erlaubnis versehen zu sein] Holz.
A monk, Dhanika [by] name, got himself wood without king Ajātaśatru's consent [lit. without being provided with the permission by king A.].
took away wood of the king Ajātaśatru without permission. Buddha heard and blamed. || But which monk,

Welcher Mönch aber Nichtgegebenes in einer Weise, die als Diebstahl zählt [wtl. Diebstahl als Zählung habend], nehmen sollte, so dass ein König ihn auf Grund solchen Nehmens von Nichtgegebenem ergreifen und ihn schlagen oder ihn binden oder ihn des Landes verweisen oder so zu ihm sprechen würde [wtl. auf Grund wie beschaffenen Nehmens von Nichtgegebenem ein König, ihn ergriffen habend, ihn schlagen ... würde]: "Du bist ein Dieb, du bist töricht, du bist dumm [bzw. du bist ein Tor, du bist ein Dummkopf], du bist ein Räuber!" - ein Mönch, der auf solche Weise Nichtgegebenes nimmt, auch dieser Mönch ist pārājika [d.h. eines Pārājika-Vergehens schuldig] [und] darf nicht mit [der Gemeinde] [zusammen]bleiben.

Which[ever] monk, however, should take a thing not given in a manner that counts as theft [lit. having theft as counting], so that a king would, because of such taking of a thing not given, would seize him and beat him or bind him or banish him from the country or speak to him thus [lit. because of such conditioned taking of a thing not given, having seized him, would beat him ...]: “You are a thief, you are foolish, you are stupid [OR: you are a fool, you are a stupe], you are a robber!” – a monk, who, in such a manner, takes a thing not given, this monk also is pārājika [i.e. guilty of a pārājika offence] [and] must not remain with [the community].
as calculation of a thief, takes away for himself what has not been given, in which way, because of carrying off what has not been given, the king, after arresting him, would beat him,
or would bind him, or would banish him from the country, or would tell him just thus: 'you are a thief, you are foolish,
you are mistaken, you are a robber', in such way, the monk taking away what has not been given, this monk also
is deprived. One should not reside with him. || How is the sin here? One moves a heavy thing (in the same way) with the intention of thief,

[Wenn] er einen schweren Gegenstand (in) [irgend]einer (Weise) in diebischer Absicht von einem Ort entfernt [wtl. fortbewegt], auch nur einen Finger[breit], [und zwar] von den [folgenden Orten:] ..., so überschreitet er den Bereich [der Verordnung] ...

[If] he, with larcenous intent, moves a heavy object (in) a[ny] (way) from a place, if only [by] a finger['s breadth], [more precisely,] from the [following places:] ..., then he transgresses the area [of the regulation] ...
from the place, even (in the distance of) a finger. || From these places, from the roof, from the cell, on the tree, on the earth, (inside the earth), in the sky,

in the air, in the water, in the boat, from the chariot, from the private land (?), one proclaims for himself on the earth (= one makes the landmarks for himself), one goes beyond or turns the village,

one gathers thieves for himself, those without foot, the two-footed, four-footed, and many-footed, one suppresses a theft, one destroys the dress (= one takes away the dress), one covers up a thief for oneself,
(if) one has put (something) in secret, beginning with it, (if) one does this sort of damage, or one orders to do,

If it is done secretly, [and] he does in some way harm to another in a com- parable manner, or causes [somebody else] to do [so], and the place (?) is full, then it is a pārājika offence. If the place is not full, then it is a grave (sthūla) offence. [If it is] somehow from a human with respect to an impor- tant [possession], then it is a pārājika offence. [If it is] like that, [but] from a non-human or an animal, then it is a grave (sthūla) offence. [If it is] somehow from a human with respect to an unimportant possession, then it is a grave (sthūla) offence. [If it is] like that, [but] from a non-human or an animal, then it is a duṣkṛta offence.
(if) the condition is filled, Pār. || (If) the condition is not filled, Sthūlātyaya. || In which case, from human being, because of a heavy thing, Pār. ||

In this case, from non-human being and from an animal, Sthūlātyaya. || In which case, from human being, because of a light thing, Sthūlātyaya. || In this case, from non-human being and from an animal, Duṣkṛta. ||
Buddha was staying on the bank of the river Phalgumatī. In the place of the forest, he taught the impurity to the monks. These monks ///

comments.comment: According to "[w]ritten in medium ductus and very clearly preserved, the manuscript is complete".
(a)mānuṣempa (first instance): the akṣara nu is added below the line.
amānuṣempa (second instance): the whole word amānuṣempa is added under the previous word; there is a cross over the "•" marking the addition.
mäṅkau: an ink rest makes the second akṣara look a bit like ṅkṣau.
mā-wṣaṣlempa: for wsaṣlempa; actually, the upper part of the ṣ looks a bit like the upper part of an s.
iprerne: the upper left stroke of the i is too long.

line.tr: The price of the law of a cakravartin king ... the omniscient ...

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

line.tr: ... having remembered, and having done this in the mind ...
... This is to be wished as a wish in all births [and] (in) all (times).
... by good behaviour after all good ones without ...
... may he spur [him] on to the nirvāṇa place with a goad (?) ...
... having done, consciousness is to be settled. All people ... Maitreya ...
... May they through ... attain the mind of the Buddha teachers!
... Thus in all births [and] in all times all virtues ...
... and all beings [are] equally friends with each other.
... May I ... as Buddha in the world. To the whole world ...

comments.comment: Probably this list of wishes is too long to have been part of a jataka. They resemble those of the Udānastotra but are less formulaic.
According to "[w]ritten [in] small to medium ductus, and very clearly preserved, it is the right edge of a five line MS."
"Written in small ductus, and very clearly preserved ... probably the left-hand edge" ().

line.tr: ·s· (t)säṅkau I have told – now I will tell the meaning of the strophes
but others gather sheep and cows to live [from]. Dear ...
Andere aber erwerben Schafe [und] Kühe, um zu überleben.
Others, however, purchase sheep [and] cows to survive.

comments.comment: Broomhead's classification as "Udānālaṅkāra" is probably based on a2, where a connection is made from strophes to an explanatory narrative. The metre is so far only found in the Anityavarga ( - ) and in .

line.tr: /// a certain merchant saw her. Suddenly
/// they prepared (the meal) for her. The householders accused her of this.
/// If a monk, not being sick, into
/// Buddha was staying in Śrāvastī. A certain patron
/// 'The one is there is āraṇyaka. Give him at first.
/// the patron got angry, then said to her.
... ärgerte sich der Gabenherr [und] sprach dann: ...
...the donator was irritated [and] then said: ...
/// Many monks (are invited to) the meal in several different houses.

line.tr: Sei [guter] Hoffnung! Du besitzest [wtl. dir sind] gute Taten [d.h. gutes Karman]. Bestimmt werden sie dich [davor] bewahren, (in der) Hölle, (bei den) Tier(en oder den Pretas [wieder]geboren zu werden).
Be in [good] hope! Yours are good deeds [i.e. good karma]. Certainly they will save you from (being [re]born in) hell, (among the) animal(s or the pretas).

comments.comment: An ornamental vertical stroke marks the left margin on the recto. A similar ornamental vertical stroke as on the recto marks the left margin of the verso; otherwise, the verso is blank, except for the leaf number.

Acording to "[w]ritten in small ductus and very clearly preserved it is the left hand edge of a manuscript with five lines on the recto, and no writing on the verso. The verso has the number five on the left. The recto seems only to have been written on at the extreme left. At the end of the first line of the recto is the number three."

comments.comment: A parallel text is found in .

The upper margin of the recto (lower of the verso) is preserved. claims that the right margin is preserved, too, but this is not certain. On the recto, the lines continue clearly beyond the edge, and on the verso, they are abraded just before the edge: possibly, the leaf consisted of two pieces of paper glued together.
According to , "in a very good state of preservation. Written in medium sized ductus".
Beginning of line: pace , tse is really not possible; with , one should rather read ntse.

comments.comment: After , recto and verso have been reversed compared to IDP. Ogihara seems to suggest that this was a 5-lines manuscript, for which I see no evidence: it is possible, but certainly not necessary, that the far right of lines a1 and b4 preserve the upper and lower margin, respectively. If Ogihara is right, the string hole space should have covered lines 2-4 of 5.
According to "[w]ritten in small ductus, and clearly preserved, it is the middle of a four line manuscript".
ks·: pace , the vocalism is not visible; only -u is excluded.

Ogihara seems to suggest that the fragment preserves 4 lines of a 5-lines leaf (). Indeed, line a1 was certainly preceded by another line, as was b4 followed by another; however, the leaf could also have had e.g. 7 lines, with my a1-4 being the original a3-5.
According to , "[w]ritten in medium ductus, and clearly preserved". A small fragment from near the Schnurloch of a large manuscript, four lines visible.
pelai(kne): on top of the pe there are three secondary inkspots.
eṅwe for eṅkwe.
Beginning of line: reads [_ṣ_ṣ_a], but the reading is disturbed by a loose piece of paper (cf. also 4 in a4); therefore, his reading cannot be confirmed.

Uv.25.8d sad evaṃ saṃgamāt satām

Uv.25.9d avarṇaś cāsya vardhate

Uv.25.10f naiva pāpasakhā bhavet
Uv.25.11b yādṛśaṃ copasevate
Uv.25.11d saṃsevā hy asya tādṛśī; the double "• •" just fills the line.

Uv.25.13a yāvajjīvaṃ pi ced bālaḥ; the wording here slightly deviates from Bernhard’s text: we expect °vaṃ pi instead of °vam api with one syllable more.
Uv.25.13c-d na sa dharmaṃ vijānāti darvī sūparasān iva, here apparently dārvī (the akṣara dā is clear).

line.tr: [TB] for the ordinary, desires are not easy to keep away. [SKT] Truly (the very variegated royal chariots) get old.
[TB] (and likewise the body) reaches old age. [SKT] but the law of the virtuous does not reach old age
[SKT] Shame be upon you, vulgar old age! [TB] Shame be upon you, vulgar old age!
Shame be upon you, vulgar old age!
[TB] thus a face gratifying to the mind [SKT] is destroyed by you
[TB] (stinking it will) without doubt (fall apart) [SKT] for life has death as its end [TB] (for life has) death (as its end)
[TB] [this body] will lie on the earth [SKT] empty and without consciousness [TB] empty (and without consciousness)
… will lie then … (85)
[SKT] with a stinking stream [streaming] steadily [from it] [TB] with a stinking stream [streaming] (steadily from it)
[SKT] with this stinking body [TB] (with) this stinking (body)

Uv.1.37a anena pūtikāyena
According to "[w]ritten in a medium sized ductus, of rather awkward and untutored appearance, it is fairly abraded, and is the middle of a five line manuscript".
According to "[w]ritten in medium ductus, and clearly preserved, it is a small fragment from the middle of a manuscript of originally at least six lines".
According to "[w]ritten in medium ductus, quite clearly preserved, three lines remain".
: "It is in quite clear state of preservation. Written in a medium ductus of awkward and somewhat untutored style".
According to "[w]ritten in medium ductus, clearly preserved, the middle of a three line portion of an MS".

transcription.prose:
70 se ṣamāne lykaṃ wārṣeṃmpa plākisa ytāri yaṃ pāyti 70-1 se ṣamāne meṅki-īkäṃ-pikwalaṃñepi onolmentse wasaṃpāt yamaṣṣäṃ pāyti su mā wasaṃpaṃnāke
ṣamāni «na»kṣalyi 70-2 se ṣamāne ṣañ ṣarsa keṃ rapanaṃ rāpatsi wat watkäṣṣäṃ pāyti 70-3 śtwer meñtsa postaññeṣ ṣamānentse pudgalyik kāko wä(rpa)
nalle tumeṃ olya wärpana«tä»r pāyti 70-4 se ṣamāne prātimokṣä-sūtär weskemane maṃt weṣṣäṃ mā ñiś yesäñ aknātsaṃs rekisa yamaskau
preku se sūtär winai abhidhārm aykemane tākaṃ pāyti 70-5 se ṣamāne śilnāntäṃ we(tāntäṃ) ṣamāneṃts klausa-pilṣi kalträ pāyti 70-6 se ṣamāne
saṅkantse pelaiykneṣṣe wäntare wätkau tākaṃ amplākätte parr«†r»a tseṅketär pāyti 70-7 (se) (ṣam)āne pañäktentse maṣṣāt yamaṣṣäṃ pāyti 70-8 se ṣam(āne)
mot māla trikelyesa śakse yokäṃ pāyti 70-9 se ṣāmāne kätkoṣ preke amplākätte kwaṣaine yinmaṣṣäṃ pāyti 80 se ṣamāne nauṣ tsaṅka(lyñe)
sa postäṃ śinmalyñesa sāṅk miyiṣṣäṃ pāyti 80-1 se ṣamāne yaka yaṣisa lānte kercyenne yaṃ parna tu-yknesa ṣärmameṃ pāyti 80-2 kUse ṣamāne prā(ti)
mokṣ po āñmt(s)a mā klyauṣäṃ pāyti 80-3 se ṣamāne ayāṣṣe kemeṣṣe sucīkār yamastär pāyti 80-4 se ṣamāne pir mañcāk yamasträ yarmtsa yamaṣälle pa(ñä)

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 b1 b2 b3 b4

line.tr: Which monk digs up the earth with his own hand, or commands [somebody else] to dig it up—pātayantika.
Auf vier Monate, und [zwar] höchstens, darf ein Mönch eine persönliche Einladung annehmen. Nimmt er darüber hinaus an, [so ist das] ein Pātayantika[-Vergehen].
Over four months, and [that is] the highest, a monk may accept a personal invitation. If he accepts beyond that, [this is] a pātayantika [offence].

Whichever monk speaks as follows when the Prātimokṣasūtra is recited, «I don't act according to the word of you [pl.], fools, [but] I will ask who may know the vinaya and the abhidharma!», [commits] a pātayantika offence. 75
Wenn ein Mönch [wtl. welcher Mönch] lauschend [dabei]steht, wenn Mönche streiten [und] kä(mpfen), [so ist das] ein Pātayantika[-Vergehen].
If a monk [lit. whichever monk] stands listening when monks argue [and] fight, [this is] a pātayantika [offence].
Which monk ordains a person under twenty—pātayantika. He will not be [sbj.] ordained. The monks are all to be reproached.
Wenn sich ein Mönch [wtl. welcher Mönch], [wenn] von der Gemeinde eine Angelegenheit des Gesetzes entschieden wird, unerlaubt nach draußen erhebt, [so ist das] ein Pātayantika[-Vergehen].
If a monk [lit. whichever monk], [when] a matter of the law is decided by the community, rises [to go] outside without consent, [this is] a pātayantika [offence].

Wenn sich ein Mönch [wtl. welcher Mönch] eine Nadelbüchse aus Knochen [oder] Elfenbein macht, [so ist das] ein Pātayantika[-Vergehen]. Wenn sich ein Mönch einen Stuhl [oder] ein Bett macht, [so ist] nach Maß zu verfahren: ...
If a monk [lit. which[ever] monk] makes a needle container from bone [or] ivory, [this is] a Pātayantika [offence]. If a monk makes for himself a chair [or] a bed, this must be done by measure:

comments.comment: Although the left and right margins are lost, the leaf preserves almost the complete text. In lines a4 and b1, an indentation of about 2 akṣaras width is found.
kṣalyi: miswritten for nakṣalyi
wärpanar: miswritten for wärpanatär
abhidhārm: r added later
aiykemane: ai is written as a with ai-vocalism
parrra: the rrr is a contamination of rr and the doubling stroke
mot māla trikelyesa śakse cf. b1
yaṣisa: ya is added under the line; the addition is marked with a cross above.

prose.s: they have been invited. (ka)kākauwa •
After the meal, Buddha gathered the community, śeśuwer postäṃ pañäkte sāṅ kraupāte •
and blamed this affair. ceU wäntare nāksate (•)

The monk should not sit or lie on a mat belonging to the monastery without extention. s(a)ṅkik raktsisa ṣam(ā)nentse • eñatketse m(ā) ceppi(l)l(e)
mā wsaṣṣälle •
He ordered to prepare a bed-roll. prastrāṃ yātka yāmtsi •
|| Buddha was staying in Śrāvastī. || pañäkte śrāvastine mäskīträ •
In the morning, he carried his alms-bowl and clothes tsoṅkaik pātrai wastsi kamāte
and entered into Śrāvastī for the alms. śrāvastine piṃtwāt yopsa •

After the meal, he carried a sitting-mat
śeśuwer postäṃ • niṣīdaṃ kamāte
and went to the forest Andhavana in order to sit in meditation. andhavaṃ warttone masa ompalskoññe lamatsi •

The venerable Kāḷodāyin followed Buddha. śaulassu kāḷodāye pañäkte o
mpostäṃ masa •
Buddha extended the sitting-mat under some tree pañäkte alyekä kca stām ñor niṣīdaṃ raksate
and sat. lyama •

Kāḷodāyin also extended the sitting-mat under some other tree through pressing against kāḷodāye rano alyekä kca stām ñor oppīläṃ
ntsa niṣīdaṃ raksate
and sat. lyama •
His body was big and both of his knees touched the earth. su no orotse kektsentsa • antapi kenīsa keṃ teksa •
Then, he said, tumeṃ weña
'Oh! au •

Buddha should order to add one span from the fringe in (every) directions (to the size of) the sitting-mat.' watkaṣṣi pi pañäkte niṣīdaṃ
ñremeṃ kälymi raso tsamtsi •
|| If a monk makes a sitting-mat, it should be made according to the measure. || lamallesa ṣamānentsa yamaskemanesa • yärmaṃssu yamaṣälle •
Here is the measure: omte se yarmä

two spans in length according to the span of Buddha, pärkarñe
sa wi rsoñcä • pañäktentse rasosa •
in width one span with half from the fringe. pkantesa śle ywārcä • ñrets raso •
If he makes it more than that, Pāt. || tumeṃ oṃṣap yāmträ • īpäṣṣeñca ||

Buddha was staying in Kapilavastu. || pañäkte kapilavā
stune mäskīträ •
If a Buddha's brother, named Nanda, enters into the community, a half of the monks were doubtful, pañäktentse procer nānde ñem • krUi sāṅne yapi sklokacci ṣamāni ywārcä mäskīyenträ •

'Is it Buddha or Nanda who entered?' pañäkte wat yopsa
nānde wat •
Nanda lacked two marks of Buddha, wi lakṣānäñcä • pañäktemeṃ nandentse meṅki ṣeṃ •
and he lacked four fingers from Buddha. śtwāra praroṃ pañäktemeṃ meṅki ṣai •

He made for himself the clothes which was similar to that of Buddha. pañäktentse wastsi
mpa sām • wastsi yamaṣṣiträ •
Buddha heard pañäkte klyauṣa
and gathered the community. sāṅ kraupāte •
He proclaimed the prescription. ce śikṣapāt śānmya •

|| If a monk makes the clothes according to the size of the clothes of Buddha, or more than that of the clothes of Buddha, Pāt. || mäksu no ṣamāne • pañäktentse
wästsintse yarmtsa wastsi yamīträ • oṃṣṣap wat pañäktäññe wästsimeṃ • īpäṣṣeñca •
Here is the size of the clothes of Buddha: omte te pañäktentse wästsintse yarmä •

nine spans in length according to the span of Buddha,
pärkarññesa ñu rsonta • pañäktäññe rasosa •
six spans in width. pkantesa ṣkas •
This is the size of the clothes of Buddha. te om(t)e pañäktentse wästsintse yarmä •

line.tr: Nach dem Essen versammelte der Buddha die Gemeinde.
After the meal, the Buddha assembled the community.

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6

line.tr: Am Morgen nahm er [scil. der Buddha] Almosenschale [und] Gewand [und] trat in Śrāvastī den Almosen[gang] an. Nach dem Essen nahm er seine Sitzmatte [und] ging in den Andhava-Wald, um in Meditation zu sitzen.

In the morning, he [i.e. the Buddha] took [his] alms bowl [and] robe [and] began his alms [round] in Śrāvastī. After [his] meal, he took his sitting mat [and] went into the Andhava forest to sit in meditation.

Der Buddha breitete sich [seine] Sitzmatte unter einem [wtl. irgendeinem] Baum aus [und] setzte sich. Auch Kāḷodāyin breitete sich [seine] Sitzmatte von gleicher Größe(?) unter einem [wtl. irgendeinem] Baum aus [und] setzte sich.

The Buddha spread out [his] sitting mat for himself under a [lit. any, some] tree [and] seated himself. Kāḷodāyin, too, spread out [his] sitting mat of equal size(?) for himself under a [lit. any, some] tree [and] seated himself.
Then he said, «Oh!, may the Buddha order to make the sitting-mat one span larger from the fringe!»
There is that measure: in length two spans according to the Buddha span, crosswise one and a half, [and] one span for the fringes. If he makes [it] more than that, [it is] a pātayantika offence.

Bei einer Sitzgelegenheit [ist] von dem Mönch, der [sie] anfertigt, nach Maß zu verfahren. Hier [wtl. da] ist das Maß: In der Länge zwei Spannen entsprechend der Spanne des Buddha, in der Breite anderthalb [Spannen] für die Fransen eine Spanne. Macht er mehr als das, [so ist das] ein Pātayantika-Vergehen.

With seating, it must be made by the monk who makes it according to measure. There is the measure: in length, two spans corresponding to the span of the Buddha, in breadth one and a half [spans] for the fringe one span. If he makes more than that, [this is] a Pātayantika offence.
Er [scil. Nanda] machte sich ein dem Gewand des Buddha gleiches Gewand.
He [i.e. Nanda] made for himself a garment alike to the Buddha's garment.
Er machte sich ein dem Gewand des Buddha gleiches Gewand.
He made for himself a robe alike to that of the Buddha.
Which monk would make a garment according to the measure of the garment of the Buddha, or exceeding the Buddha garment—pātayantika.
Wenn sich aber ein Mönch [wtl. welcher Mönch] ein Gewand nach dem Maß des Gewandes des Buddha oder über das Buddhagewand hinaus macht, [so ist das] ein Pātayantika[-Vergehen].
If, however a monk [lit. which[ever] monk] makes for himself a garment according to the measure of the Buddha's garment, or beyond the Buddha's garment, [this is] a Pātayantika [offence].

prose.s: ninety, O venerable ones, Pāt. (lit. making someone fall)-dharmas have been recited by me. śaulassoñcä ñumka • īpäṣṣeñcana pelaiknenta •
Here I as before. || omte ñäś mäkte nauṣ ||

|| O venerable ones, now these four Pratid. (lit. to be reported)-dharmas come to the recitation of Prātimokṣasūtra each half month. || cai no ś(aula)ssoñcä śtw(ā)ra wrantsai aksaṣṣäl(yana) (pe)
laiknenta artsa ywarca meñ prātimokṣäṣṣepi sutarntse akṣalñene ecce känmaskeṃ •
|| Buddha was staying in Śrāvastī. || pañ(ä)kte śrāvastine mäskīträ •

Then, it was the time of hunger. ot no k(e)
statse preke ṣai •
A lot of honor and reverence turned to the nun Utpalavarṇā. uppalavarṇañ aśiyantse • yarke peti māka sporttīträ •
She obtained much food. māka śwatsanma kälpāṣṣi •

She gave it as food to the monks. tu ṣamā
nets päst aiṣṣi śwātsi •
The third day came to her, tāy no trite kauṃ ṣai •
(that) she remained without eating. eśuwacca mäskīträ •
Thereafter, the attack of weakness seized her. tumeṃ leswi eṅsanta-ne •
She was still walking and fell on the street. yaka ynemane nauntaine klāya •

A certain merchant saw her.
käryorttau ksa lyakā-ne •
Suddenly he returned (to his home) ista= klautka •
and informed his wife. śnoy ākṣa •
Thereafter, she came, tumeṃ sāU śem
kauc ersate-ne •
carried her oskai wayāte-ne •
and prepared food for her. śwātsi wäṅkṣāte-ne •

Buddha heard pañäkte
klyauṣa
and blamed. nāksate

|| If a monk, not being sick, seizes hard food and soft food by his own hand from an unrelated nun who enters into one house for alms, it should be reported to other monks by this monk. || mäksu no ṣamāne mā alāṣmo eneṅka osne piṃtwātäśc ynemane • aletsai aśiyaimeṃ • ṣañ ṣarsa trās(k)a
lye • tsāltalye eñcīträ • ceU ṣamānentsa • ṣamānents āksaṣälle •
'O venerable ones, I have violated a point by something to be blamed. nakṣalyesa śaulassoñc īke kätkau nesau •

What is not suitable should be announced. mā ayāto a
ksaṣṣälye •
I announce this point. cew īke aksaskau •
This is a rule to be reported.' || se pelaikne wrantsai aksaṣṣälle • ||
|| Buddha was staying in Śrāvastī. || pañäkte śrāvastine mäskīträ •

A certain patron invited the monks and the nuns to the meal. tanāpate ksa ṣamā
neṃ aśiyana ṣpä śwātsiś kakāte •
Thereafter, Sthūlanandā informed the patron: tumeṃ sthulanānda ceU tanāpateṃ śarsäṣṣi •
'The one is there is āraṇyaka. samp arāññe ste
Give him at first. cwim nauṣ pete •

Then, these are āgamadharas.
caim no agamadhari skente •
He is ābhidhārmika. sam no abhidharmike ste •
He is vinayadhara.' sam winasāre •
Therefore, the patron got angry. tusa tanāpate kraṣiyate •
'Order, you. twe pitka

and blamed. nāksate

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6

line.tr: Der Nonne Utpalavarṇā wandte sich viel Verehrung [und] Ehrerbietung zu [d.h. wurde viel Verehrung und Ehrerbietung zuteil].
Much reverence and obeisance [was] turned towards the nun Utpalavarṇā [i.e. was bestowed upon her].
Darauf ergriff sie [scil. die Nonne Utpalavarṇā] ein Schwächeanfall.
Thereupon, she [i.e. the nun Utpalavarṇā] was seized by a dizzy spell.
Darauf kam sie, hob sie auf [wtl. richtete sie auf], führte sie in [ihre] Behausung [und] bereitete(?) ihr Essen.
Thereupon she came, lifted her up, led her into [her] home [and] prepared(?) food for her.

Which monk not being ill goes into the inside of a house for alms-begging, and takes hard and soft food with his own hand from an unrelated nun, that monk has to confess to the monks: 'In a condemnable matter, o honourable ones, I have trespassed [lit. crossed the place].'

Ein Gabenherr lud die Mönche und Nonnen zum Essen ein. Darauf belehrte Sthūlanandā den Gabenherren: 'Jener ist ein Āraṇyaka, gib ihm zuerst! Doch jene sind Āgamadharas; jener aber ist ein Ābhidhārmika; jener ein Vinayadhara(?).' Der Gabenherr ärgerte sich darüber. 'Befiehl du, wir [aber] sollen ruhig bleiben [wtl. sitzen]'.

A donator invited the monks and nuns to a meal. Thereupon Sthūlanandā instructed the donator: 'That one is an Āraṇyaka, give [food] to him first! But those are Āgamadharas; that one, however, is an Ābhidhārmika; that one a Vinayadhara(?).' The donator was irritated by this. 'You, command [us], [but] we shall sit still'.
Because of that the benefactor was upset, [and said], 'You order! We will remain quiet.'

If monks were invited into dwellings to eat on the way (?), and a nun were standing there giving instructions, 'Give rice here!', 'Give soup here!', 'Give more here!', [then] this nun should be [addressed] by the monks like this …

The author of this letter seems to be a creditor who now demands his money.

comments.comment: According to "[w]ritten in medium ductus, and slightly abraded both sides, it is the left edge of a six line manuscript".

Lines a6 and b1 are lost. This fragment can hardly be from the same manuscript as : the hands are clearly different, and, while consists of sheats of paper glued together, there are no indications that the same is true of this fragment. Nevertheless, it is striking that the line lengths are identical, both having 2 pādas per line. In addition, ends with pāda 18a and this fragment begins with pāda 18c. However, a closer look shows that the leaf preceding this fragment must have contained at least also 18b, since only the end of 18c is preserved, directly after the string hole space (and thus quite far to the left, in any case well before the middle, of the original leaf). In view of the fact that preserves only the beginning of 18b, it can be excluded that they are subsequent leaves of the same manuscript.
Note that lines b2–6 are numbered b1–5 by .
cf. a3 ṣamāññempa eraitwe ¦ cimpim palsko yātässi ¦ āstreṃ yāmtsi • [24c]
cf. a3-4 paramārth pelaikne ¦ trai śaiṣentso tarnene ¦ aṣāṃ aitsi : [25a] mārgavārgṣe kauṃ śpālmeṃ ¦ paiykalyñesa stamoy sā ¦ walke ytārye : [25b]
cf. a4-5 tek yäknesa śpālmeṃ ñiś ¦ yamim pākri oktatsai ¦ klyomñai ytāri : [25c] (= a1 pāda 19c)
cf. a5 satkāravārg paiykāmai ¦ po krentaunaṃts sa(naṃ ce)u ¦ lābhasatkār [26a] (= a2 pāda 20a)
cf. b1 tsirauwñeṣṣe kauṣn āya ¦ ompalskoṣṣe mrestīwe ¦ pakṣäṃ ysomo • [26c] (= a2 pāda 20c)
cf. b4 po krentaunaṃts śmoññai ce ¦ paiykalñesa smṛtivārg ¦ akālk kñītär-ñ : [28a] (= a5 pāda 22a)
cf. b4-5 krent āksalñe ṣek ā(ks)oym ¦ tarya śpāl(m)eṃ (n)aumyenta ¦ araṃśn= eṅku : [28c] (= a6 pāda 22c)
cf. b1 [b1] ¦ āksau tākoy-ñ : [23a] (= b5 pāda 29a)

cf. perhaps b1 /// ·ñ(eṣ)ṣ(e) ṣarm – /// [23c]. However, the traces of may be syllables 10-12 of this pāda, i.e. syllables 3-5 of the second unit of 7 syllables, while we would for IOL Toch 281 rather expect approximately syllables 16-18.
cf. perhaps b2 paikalñesa udakavārg ¦ po ekṣalyiṃ po(yśñana) /// [24a]. Again, the traces of IOL Toch 281 may have to be positioned rather towards the end of the pāda, which is not preserved in .

comments.comment: Lower (of side a) left part of a leaf. The left margin is preserved in a3 and b1.

ṣ·: ṣ(a) can be excluded grammatically. As palaeographical possibilities remain, then, ṣ(e) and ṣ(i), of which the latter is the only ending that makes sense grammatically: without doubt an adjective in -ṣi modifying koññäktes.
Line a3 is in cursive script.

line.tr: ... im Übermaß [wtl. zuviel] genossen, trocknet [sie] die Kehle aus, bedrückt das Herz [und] macht [es] schlaff, ... macht allmählich den Stuhlgang kümmerlich, träge(?), hart [und] fest [und] ruft außer diesen noch weitere [wtl. dies usw.] Windkrankheiten hervor.

... consumed in excess [lit. too much], [it] dries up the throat, oppresses the heart [and] makes [it] limp, ..., gradually makes dejection poor, slow(?), hard [and] firm [and], apart from these, it causes other [lit. these, etc.] wind-illnesses.
Now I will recite the incompatibilities.
Whenever I recite the incompatibilities, this [is] to be understood.

Wann immer ich Unverträglichkeiten lehre, [ist] dies zu wissen: Auf diese Weise [d.h. Unverträgliches] gegessen habend, [ist] mit Vomieren zu behandeln [und] mit Purgieren zu behandeln. Wenn [dies] aber nicht gemacht wird, ruft [es] Wundrose, Wasserbauch [und] Ausschlag mit Pusteln hervor, oder es entstehen Fisteln, ...

Whenever I teach intolerances, this [is] to be known: having eaten in this way [i.e. something intolerable], [this] must be treated with vomiting [and must] be treated with laxation. If, however, [this] is not done, [it] will cause erysipelas, abdominal dropsy [and] a rash with pustules, or fistulas will develop, ...

But if one does not do [it], [this] causes erysipelas, hydropsy and praśśāṅkaṃ, or [he has] haemorrhoids, is blind, drugged, obstructed, or [he] even [has] diseases such as snaittu, leprosy, emaciation, fever, jaundice, cholera [or] insanity.
Now I will recite the power[s] of the medicines.

pada.s:
... by the heart, [the patient is] sharp (= acid) in the mouth. (ara)
ñcsa • räskare koyne •
Recognise the above (lit. before) as a symptom of cancer due to gall. pittaṣṣepi kwaṃrmatse nauṣ ṣotri pkarsaso •
He always becomes light (= bitter) in the mouth, ... laṃtse koyne ṣek mäsketrä ///

(likewise he becomes breathless) as if carrying a burden,
perpette premane ra
and he may vomit aṅkain yamalle ṣp
[and] his nostrils are blocked up. melyi taṅki mäskeṃnträ •
Anxiety (= nausea) besets his body, iwate kektseṃne mäsketär-ne

[he is] confused and gets (sleepy during the day at inappropriate) moments. trik(au) ///
preke mäsketär-ne •
He has no appetite for food śwātsi mā āñme
[and] his body is constantly satiated. somotkäṃñe sosoyusa kektseñe mäsketä(r-n)e

... Recognise (the above as a symptom) of cancer due to phlegm. /// (pkarsa)
so kwärmatse leśpaṣṣepi ||
Now I will tell the medicine. ñake sāṃtke weñau •
10 trau of Trigonella corniculata are to be cooked in milk. corak traunta 10 malkwerne pä(kṣalle)

... (This is to be drunk as) medicine (against cancer). /// (sāṃ)
tke ||
Sesame oil, milk, honey, [and] syrup are to be cooked in a vessel ṣalype kuñcitäṣṣe • malkwer mit panit aisene päkṣalle
[so that] half [of it] remains. ... ywārtsa lipāträ •

... pepper is to be strewed in – ///
pippāl eneṃ kätnālle
this is to be drunk as a medicine against cancer. te yokalle kwärmatse sāṃtke • ||

Sesame paste, castor-oil plant (are to be mixed with vinegar) as an ointment against cancer. kuñcīt mlyokotau • irant a /// (kwä)
rmattse laupe ||
A molasses pill [is] the first (lit. one) remedy, panitäṣṣe ṣpel ṣe prayok •
fenugreek the second, wetene se wate •
a fish-gill pill (the third) ... läksaiñai (klau)tsaiṣṣe ///

... the fourth,
śtarte •
saltpetre the fifth. yavakṣār piṅkte •
These remedies are to be drunk with milk as a medicine against cancer. toy prayokänta malkwersa yokalyi kwärmatse sāṃtke ||
(This tumour belongs to both) the gall (and wind. pi(tta) ///

It occurs in [fertile] women only [and]) it does not occur in [fertile] men.
mā su mäsketär śrānäts
I will now tell the symptom also of this. cwi rano ṣotri • weñau •

When it has not moved (?) for a long time when it is moved, or when it is moved suddenly, or when it is moved suddenly for [some] time, ... their [i.e. of the women] abdomen grows, mā walkeññe päst yā(mormeṃ) ///
yāmormeṃ istak wat päst yāmormeṃ • istak wat prekesa yāmorme(ṃ) • y·… ///
tso staukkanatär-me
likewise the [menstrual] blood stands still. śle yasar kalträ
It is by the women valued as [being] pregnant. klainats preṃtsa ynāñm yamasträ

Further the abdomen is burning hot ... becomes ... mäntak no tso erkatse sa ///
…r mäsketrä •
[Her] breasts have (= develop) froth, päścane leśpsa mäsketär
[she is] pale of appearance erene yolyiya
and she gets the desire [of a pregnant woman]. āñme ṣpä mäsketär-ne

prose.s: Vomiting ...aṅkaiṃ ///

line.tr: wird sich erbrechen
will vomit
Now I shall state the remedy (91)
Sesame oil, milk, honey, syrup should be cooked in a vessel so that half of it remains… (91)
Sesamöl, Milch, Honig [und] Syrup [sind] in Überschuss zu kochen. Die Hälfte [davon] soll übrigbleiben.
Sesame oil, milk, honey [and] syrup must be cooked in excess. Half [of it] shall remain.
I will also state the symptom [lit. sign] of it (91)
von den Frauen wird er ... gewürdigt
by the women he is ... valued highly
... (nicht) wird der Penis ihnen schlaff, [sondern] steht im Blut/ steht, mit Blut [gefüllt], [und] wird von den Frauen [als] zeugungsfähig geschätzt.
... the[ir] penis does not go limp, [but] stands [filled] with blood, [and] is evaluated by the women as procreative.
