pada.s:
... may I always be without negligence towards all virtues, having indefatigable energy in order to destroy ...!
; (s)n(ai-y)k(orñe) ñäś , ṣek tākoym ; po krentaunaścä :

May I through the Priyavarga be able to remove the love for the life [and] the body forever! priyavārgsa , larauñe ; śaul kektsenn(e) ,
(ynau)ṣk(a) ra ; cämpim muṣsi
What[ever] little sorrow [it] is, its cause [is] all clinging. kUse cek warñai , lakle ste ; tuntse ṣarm po , eṅkalyñe ;
May I always know this! te ṣek karsoym •

May I through the writing of this jewel of a Śīlavarga, [which is] like a diadem of instruction, observe more than [my own] life all rules of good conduct, one by one. mahūr ram no , śāsantse ; śilavārgṣe , naumye ce ; paiyka
l(y)ñesa :
śaultsa auṣap , paṣṣīmar ; śīlaṣṣana , sälyaino ; po yke postäṃ :

May I not let go the sevenfold conduct of life, even [when] separated from the Omniscient! ṣuk-yäknesa , śaul-śīlo ; wätkau rano , poyśinmeṃ ; mā ceU
(tarko)ym :
May I observe the way of the ten actions; śak-karmaṣṣai , ytāri tāU ; paṣṣimar ñiś ;
may I make [it] descend onto others. kārpäṣṣim , alyeṅkäṃnne :

May I through the writing of the excellent Sucaritavarga be standing on precisley that. sucarita,vārg śpālmeṃ ; paiykalyñesa , tāko
(y)m ñ(i)ś ; tukne stmauwo :
May I with body, speech [and] mind always refrain carefully from bad conduct! kektseñ reki , palskosa ; ṣek wlāwoymar , anaiśai ; duścaritmeṃ :

May I always be without harm towards all beings with body, speech [and] mind! snai mīyäṣlñe , ṣek tākoym ; kektseñ reki , palskosa ; po wno
l(me)nn(e) :
May I reach the place of extinction that has been made known by the king of the Ṛṣis together with someone dear to him! rṣākeṃts lānte , śeśśarsoṣ ; yänmoym īke , kekesoṣ ; cwī larempa :

May through the writing of the Vācavarga never go out from my mouth untrue speech by which I might destroy myself or bring harm upon someone else. paiykalñesa , vācavārg ; waiyke reki , mantanta ; läññi-ñ (k)o
ynm(e)ṃ (:)
And may I not with irritated mind say any word that [would] not [be] approved of by the good ones! mamāntaṣ «ṣ»pä , palskosa ; mā ñiś reki , weñim nta ; krentaṃts m= ārtaṣ :

May those who have been born in the hells because of untrue speech be redeemed! wai
yk(e) reki , ṣärmameṃ ; kUse tetemoṣ , nraintane ; cai tsälponträ :
I have written the Karmavarga – karmavārgä , paiykāmai ;
may I always be conscious of cause [and] effect! ṣarm okone , imasu ; ṣek ñīś tākoym :

The fruit of an act, even a fine one, even a little one, does not disappear – lykaśke rano , to(tka)
ra ; yāmornts= oko , mā nakṣtär ;
may I always know that! te ṣek karsoymä :
May my spirit in all births [and] in all times turn away from evil deeds! po cmelane , po preśyaṃ ; yāmorntameṃ , yolaina ; klautkoy-ñä palsko :

Even in the other world there is nothing more [important] than the deed – eṃṣke alyek , ś(ai)
(ṣṣ)e(n)e ; yāmors= olpo , mā nesäṃ ;
may the beings know [it]! karsoṃ wnolymi :
May I by the jewel of a Śraddhāvarga obtain this fruit for sure in all births: śraddhavārgṣe , naumyesa ; källoym oko , nemcek ce ; po cmelane :

May I always have strong faith in the deed, good or bad. perākäññe ,
(mai)yyātstse ; ṣek ñi tākoy , yāmorne ; kreṃnt yolaiṃ wat :
May I seize the shame [and] modesty praised by the wise [and] dear to the good. papālaṣ cau , aiśaumyeṃts ; krentaṃts lareṃ , eñcīmar ; yase kwīpe :

May I always have the consciousness [that is] (permanently?) dressed in good conduct [and] directed towards the law. śīlne ausu ,
(e)ṃ(ṣk)e(ts)e ; (p)elaikne , ykū-ime ; ṣek ñī tākoy
May I through the writing of this excellent Śramaṇavarga destroy the passion of thirst! śramaṇavārgä , śpāl(m)eṃ ce ; (p)ai(ka)lyñesa , kars(t)oym«†ä» ñiś ; yokai kleśo :

(May I recognise the fault in the cauldron of clinging to) turning the [cycle of] birth! nano camel , s(p)ā
(rtässi) ;

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6

line.tr: Mehr als das [eigene] Leben möchte ich fortwährend die Richtlinien des sittlichen Verhaltens ganz bewahren.
More than [my own] life, may I keep the rules of moral conduct entirely at all times.
Mit Körper, Wort [und] Denken möchte ich mich stets sorgfältig von dem schlechten Wandel zurückhalten [wtl. beherrschen].
With body, speech [and] thought, may I at all times refrain [lit. control myself] from bad conduct.
Durch das Schreiben des Vācavarga möge mir niemals ein Lügenwort (aus) dem Munde herausgehen, durch das ich mich selbst zerstören oder einem anderen Schädigung bringen könnte.
By writing the Vācavarga, may no word of falsehood ever leave my mouth, by which I could destroy myself or inflict damage on someone else.

Den Karmavarga habe ich geschrieben [in dem Wunsche]: Der Ursache [und] Wirkung möchte ich stets eingedenk sein. [Mag] sie [scil. die Tat] auch klein [und] auch gering [sein], die Frucht der Tat geht nicht zugrunde, dies möchte ich immer erkennen. In allen Geburten, zu allen Zeiten möchte sich mein Denken von den bösen Taten abwenden.

The Karmavarga I have written [wishing]: May I always be conscious of cause [and] effect. Even if it [i.e. the deed] [be] small [and] even [if it be] slight, the fruit of the deed never perishes, may I always know this. In all births, at all times, may my thought always turn away from the evil deeds.

comments.comment: The diphthong ai is consistently written ‹aiy› before k: a2-3 paiykal(ñ)esa; a4 paiykalyñesa; a6 paiykalñesa; a6 waiyke; b1-2 waiyk(e); b2 paiykāmai. The only exception is b6 (p)elaikne. Remarkable is further the ly in b4 wnolymi. Virāma is lacking a couple of times; see the metrical analysis above.
Lines a1-b6, i.e. the whole leaf, correspond to a1-b5; lines b5-6 correspond to a1-2.

The text is written in a metre of 4x18 syllables, divided 7 ¦ 7 ¦ 4; each unit of 7 can be further subdivided into 4 + 3 syllables. This leaf comprises pādas 12a–18b. [a1] ¦ (s)n(ai)-(y)k(orñe) ñäś ṣek tākoym ¦ po krentaunaścä : [12a] ekwalatte-tsirauñe ¦ nautässi – – – – mñen= ¦ āsa (wa)rñai : [12b] priyavārgsa larauñe ¦ śaul kektsenn(e) [a2] (ynau)ṣk(a) ra ¦ cämpim muṣsi [12c] kuse cek warñai lakle ste ¦ tuntse ṣarm po eṅkalyñe ¦ te ṣek karsoym • (1)2 mahūr ram no śāsantse ¦ śilavārgṣe naumye ce ¦ paiyka [a3] l(y)ñesa : [13a] śaultsa auṣap paṣṣīmar ¦ śīlaṣṣana sälyaino ¦ po yke postäṃ : [13b] ṣuk-yäknesa śaul-śīlo ¦ wätkau rano poyśinmeṃ ¦ mā ceu
[a4] (tarko)ym : [13c] śak-karmaṣṣai ytāri tāu ¦ paṣṣimar ñiś kārpäṣṣim ¦ alyeṅkäṃnne : 13 sucaritavārg śpālmeṃ ¦ paiykalyñesa tāko [a5] (y)m ñ(i)ś ¦ tukne stmauwo : [14a] kektseñ reki palskosa ¦ ṣek wlāwoymar anaiśai ¦ duścaritmeṃ : [14b] snai mīyäṣlñe ṣek tākoym ¦ kektseñ reki palskosa ¦ po wno [a6] l(me)nn(e) : [14c] rṣākeṃts lānte śeśśarsoṣ ¦ yänmoym īke kekesoṣ ¦ cwī larempa : 14 paiykalñesa vācavārg ¦ waiyke reki mantanta ¦ läññi-ñ (k)o [b1] ynm(e)ṃ (:) [15a] kucesa ṣañ-añmä karstoymar ¦ alyekepi kaloym wat ¦ mīyäṣṣälyñe : [15b] mamāntaṣ 〈ṣ〉pä palskosa ¦ mā ñiś reki weñim nta ¦ krentaṃts m= ārtaṣ : [15c] wai [b2] yk(e) reki ṣärmameṃ ¦ kuse tetemoṣ nraintane ¦ cai tsälponträ : 15 karmavārgä paiykāmai ¦ ṣarm okone imasu ¦ ṣek ñīś tākoym : [16a] lykaśke rano to(tka) [b3] ra ¦ yāmornts= oko mā nakṣtär ¦ te ṣek karsoymä : [16b] po cmelane po preśyaṃ ¦ yāmorntameṃ yolaina ¦ klautkoy-ñä palsko : [16c] eṃṣke alyek ś(ai) [b4] (ṣṣ)e(n)e ¦ yāmors= olpo mā nesäṃ ¦ karsoṃ wnolymi : 16 śraddhavārgṣe naumyesa ¦ källoym oko nemcek ce ¦ po cmelane : [17a] perākäññe [b5] (mai)yyātstse ¦ ṣek ñi tākoy yāmorne ¦ kreṃnt yolaiṃ wat : [17b] papālaṣ cau aiśaumyeṃts ¦ krentaṃts lareṃ eñcīmar ¦ yase kwīpe : [17c] śīlne ausu [b6] (e)ṃ(ṣk)e(ts)e ¦ (p)elaikne ykū ime ¦ ṣek ñī tākoy 17 śramaṇavārgä śpāl(m)eṃ ce ¦ (p)ai(ka)lyñesa kars(t)oym ñiś ¦ yokai kleśo : [18a] nano camel s(p)ā(rtässi) [18b] Virāma is lacking a couple of times. According to the metre, one has to read: 12a po krentaunaśc for po krentaunaścä; 15b ṣañ-añm for ṣañ-añmä; 16b karsoym for karsoymä; 16c klautkoy-ñ for klautkoy-ñä; 18a śramaṇavārg for śramaṇavārgä. In general, one can say that if an extra final syllable is metrically needed, it is mostly written ‹-o›, not ‹-ä› (13b sälyaino; 13c śīlo; 14a stmauwo; 18a kleśo). An exception is 16a karmavārgä. Not conforming to the internal 4+3 pattern of the 7-syllable unit is 14a sucaritavārg śpālmeṃ. On 17c see the text notes.
krentaunaśca : read with final a = ä instead of a because of the preceding ś (). However, according to the metre one should read rather krentaunaśc\ (see below).
ñäś: this reading is the most likely, in spite of the fact that the manuscript has ñiś elsewhere.
ekwalatte-tsirauñe: a bahuvrīhi compound referring to the subject, the "I".

nautässi – – – – mñen= āsa (wa)rñai: Pinault and Malzahn (see ) restore nautässi(ś yolo śā)mñen= āsa (wa)rñai 'in order to destroy (evil) in (human) [nature] beginning with the head'. This is possible, but needs the assumption that āsa stands for āssa, a later form of āṣtsa ().

(ynau)ṣk(a): this restoration, suggested by Pinault and Malzahn (see ), is possible only if ynauṣkak, attested two times ( b3, a1), stands for /ynáwṣkak/ (not for /ynawṣkə́k/). This in turn implies that ynauṣak, attested only once ( a1), is either a reading or a writing mistake for ynauṣkak, because there is no suffix to derive /ynáwṣkak/ from **/ynawṣə́k/.
śaul-śīlo: apparently a compound.
stmauwo: w seems a correction of some other akṣara, perhaps m.
wlāwoymar: literally 'may I control myself'.
īke kekesoṣ: literally 'extinct place', here without doubt 'place of extinction'.
kekesoṣ: the transcription of incorrectly has postäṃ instead (Ronald I. Kim, p.c.).
yolaina: misread as yolaine in .
(mai)yyātstse: b3 reads eṃṣketstse instead. The reading in was not correct.

(e)ṃ(ṣk)e(ts)e: a reading laukañe v.s. as in a1 can be excluded. If this reading is correct, the following (p)elaikne may have to be corrected into pelaiknene because of the metre (see directly below).

(p)elaikne ykū: certainly a calque, cf. Skt. dharmagata "auf den Dharma gerichtet" (). According to the metre, (p)elaikne is to be corrected into pelaiknene (cf. a1). However, if the reading (e)ṃ(ṣk)e(tsts)e (see above) is wrong, one could also consider taking the preceding syllable syntactically with this expression, e.g. (kr)e(nt p)elaikne 'the good law'.
kars(t)oym: for this reading, cf. b5. Though illegible, a trace of the element below the ‹s› can be discerned.
yokai: missing in the transcription of .

record.references: volume IV plate CLII IOL Toch 307

In , this line was read /// tno tpāt[\], 1 [po] ///. Without making explicit why, prefers to read /// nto rwā taṃ p· ///. Although one may disagree on some details, I can definitely not accept his reading rwā. My current reading (ci)ttotpāt po(sāt) sees here a Tocharianised form of Skt. cittotpādapoṣatha "Beichtfeier aufgrund des Fassens eines Vorsatzes, Entschlusses" ( II: 253a).

comments.comment: Although the fragments IOL Toch 579 (left, original size w: 3,9 cm, h: 4,4 cm) and IOL Toch 1187 (right, original size w: 3,6 cm, h: 4,4 cm) were edited separately in , they clearly belong together. There are no lines missing between a5 and b1, even though the lower margin of the recto (upper of the verso) is not itself preserved. The blank space to the left is probably not the string hole space (pace ) because it seems to cover also line a5, which is the last; therefore, the left margin must be preserved. Still, the leaf number is not preserved: perhaps it stood left of lines b4-5.

m[ā]: The reading is not certain. It could also be rme of Uv.13.7d dharmeṇa na vaṇik caret. If it is really mā, it may be TB mā 'not', rendering Skt. na of the same line. The TB translation may have been pelaiknesa mā karyor yāmi.
Uv.13.8b nānyeṣāṃ spṛhako bhavet. The akṣara spṛ is difficult to read because a tiny piece is flipped over from the verso, see the comment to line b4.
Uv.13.8d samādhiṃ nādhigacchati. The following traces, illegible by themselves, must be [8] (s)[ukh](aṃ), the beginning of Uv.13.9a sukhaṃ jīvitum icchec cet.
Uv.13.9b-c śrāmaṇyārtheṣv avekṣavān / ahir mūṣakadurgaṃ vā, here apparently with ahi for ahir, as no r can be read on top of the akṣara mū.
Uv.13.10a-b sukhaṃ jīvitum icchec cec chrāmaṇyārtheṣv avekṣavān
Uv.13.10d ekadharmaṃ ca bhāvayet
Uv.13.11c sāṃghikaṃ nāvamanyeta. The following [s]· is the beginning of the TB translation of sāṃghikaṃ, possibly saṅkaṣṣe v.s.
Uv.13.12a-b alpajñāto ’pi ced bhavati śīleṣu susamāhitaḥ
śīle[ṣ]u: the ś is closed at the bottom and looks a bit like s .
Uv.13.12d śuddhājīvam atandritam
(a)s(t)are śaul: a5 reads āstreṃ śaul, a verse variant of regular prose astare.

śaul [ś]·[y]e·ai: the reading l [ś]· is problematic because the ś seems to be attached directly below the l . If śaul śayeñcai was written together, one would at all times expect an akṣara lśa, not lśa. Probably, the scribe mixed up the two possible spellings lśa in one akṣara and l \ śa in two akṣaras. The ś is partly readable in the reconstructed image, but part of it was flipped over to the recto (see the comment to line a2) on the original image.
Uv.13.13c alpajñātam iti jñātvā
ra is added below the line.
kr· seems to be added below the line.

comments.comment: A remarkable fragment that looks as if it is from a leaf glued together from two leaves and afterwards folded out – the more so because there is a big space in the middle and the left text is upside down, and also because it has a line in the middle which is approximately the line which mirrors the edges. Contradicting this is the fact that there are a recto and a verso that are not the same. I divided both recto and verso in two, just as they are on the CD.

: apparently only skāroy and āroy are attested as possible forms

Although extremely fragmentary, this fragment is reminiscent of the casuistics of the Vinayavibhaṅga: se westrä ‘this means’ and (kä)r(sa)nalle ‘is to be understood’ or (päst tä)r(ka)nalle ‘is to be given back’. maiyyaṃñe may refer to the use of force as in e.g. (“Gewalt”); leki wat, if correctly read, may refer to e.g. pātayantika 14.
: probably a form of ‘burn’, pälkemane or pälketär. Perhaps another vowel is also possible (o?), which would also allow pälkoṣ etc.
something like leki wat is possible.
possible, in theory, forms such kärkanalle, tärkanalle, wärpanalle, kärsanalle. Only the first is semantically unlikely. E.g. päst tärkanalle.

comments.comment: (s)n(ai)-m(i)yäṣṣälñeccu: this restoration is possible, but not evident. This would correspond to anavadya vs., which yielded thus far no hits.
udumpa: certainly a form of udumpar* (Skt. udumbara-), cf. TA ūdūmparṣi b4.
: probably a Buddhastotra in view of the voc. in a1
pā ·i: = pā(kr)i?

ṣmeṃ: This syllable occurs mainly in auṣmeṃ / oṃṣmeṃ, and as a spelling variant in ṣmeñca, i.e. often osta-ṣmeñca 'householder'. Here it may be possible to read the next akṣara as c, so (osta)-ṣmeṃc(a) + nts. If correct, this may point to the vinaya.
: the only possible key-word is kloka///, which could be a form of klokaśce ‘pore, follicle’.

yamäṣṣäṃ must describe the effect of the medicine, and the preceding word is most probably an adjective. The only attested combination possible is sticce Sa2.
nakänmā, tekanma?
pätso seems to be the nom.sg. of obl.sg. patsa, unattested so far.
triwäṣle is impossible.
One would think of koṣkaine, but an ai-vowel seems excluded; o perhaps still possible.

Certainly a form of ‘pupil’, but where is the a? in this late shape one wouldn’t expect sandhi writing and there is no place for an initial a-. Perhaps the initial a- is really dissolved in sandhi (not only in writing)? Then it would have to be verse.

comments.comment: On IDP, the images are upside down.
Uv.24.30b saṃvatsaraṃ yajati puṇyaprekṣī

This is a difficult line, because the Sanskrit text is lacking. lki, which can be read if the piece flipped over to the verso is considered, must be from telki and combined with yam- it must mean ‘honour’ or ‘sacrifice’ (the equation telki ~ yajña is attested in a4). ’s reconstruction puṇyaprekṣī is confirmed by yarpo lk· ///, which must contain a form of ləka- ‘see’, but his yajati may have to be turned into yajeta in view of the opt. in Tocharian B yāmi (and cf. Dhp.108b yajetha).
Uv.24.30d abhivādanaṃ tv ṛjjugateṣu śreyaḥ

After (ke)k(a)moṣ, the word saim can be read, but the lower part of the ligature mXā is unclear. I would expect a form of yam- ‘to do’ and the following akṣara could either be mi or mo, both giving good possibilities (i.e. either yāmo° or yāmi), but it looks more like m[n]ā, so that I would like to leave this question open.
Uv.25.1b piśunair vibhūtinandibhiḥ
I expect wṣetstse or the like as a translation of piśuna, but there are no rests below the t. Maybe it is just very badly abraded.
Uv.25.2a śrāddhebhiḥ peśalebhiś ca
Uv.25.2c sākhyaṃ kurvīta saprajñaḥ
Uv.25.4c teṣāṃ hi śrutvā tu subhāṣitāni

Uv.25.5c śreṣṭham upagato hy upaiti śraiṣṭhyaṃ. We clearly read śre, so probably śre(ṣṭham), against Bernhard’s reconstruction śraiṣṭhyaṃ Uv. 25.5c, just like (śr)e(ṣṭham) in a8.
Uv.25.6a śreyo hi labhate nityaṃ
Uv.25.6d śīlenopaśamena ca

comments.comment: The upper margin of the recto (lower of the verso) is preserved. Lines a1-4 cover the 6 half pādas 4.1d-4.3a, lines b3-6 the 6 half pādas 4.4e-4.5d: the 7 half pādas in between will have covered two lines on each side and the total number of lines must have been 6. On IDP, recto and verso are reversed.
Uv.4.1d ye pramattāḥ sadā mṛtāḥ, see Dhp.21 (and )

smṛtā(ḥ) seems to be an error for mṛtāḥ, possibly induced by sadā (also in the Tib. version, see ), which corresponds to yathā in e.g. the Dhp. Thus, Dhp.21d ye pamattā yathā matā 'the careless are as though [already] dead' () corresponds to ye pramattāḥ sadā smṛtāḥ 'who are negligent are always remembered' in this version (this reading is not given by ).
Uv.4.2a-b etāṃ viśeṣatāṃ jñātvā hy apramādasya paṇḍitaḥ, see Dhp.22 (and )
The hiatus-resolving hy is lacking before apramā(dasya) (this occurs frequently with these pādas divided in two, because there is no hiatus anyway, cf. , and e.g. a3 as(m)iṃ for hy asmiṃ).
Uv.4.2c apramādaṃ pramudyeta, see Dhp.22 (and )
Uv.4.3a apramattāḥ sātatikā, see Dhp.23(and )
Uv.4.4e parvatasthaiva bhūmisthāṃ, see Dhp.28 (and )
Uv.4.4f dhīro bālān avekṣate, see Dhp.28 (and )
Uv.4.5b saṃyamena damena ca, see Dhp.25 (and )
Uv.4.5c-d dvīpaṃ karoti medhāvī tam ogho nābhimardati, see Dhp.25 (and )

Uv.16.11b-c/12b-c maraṇānte ca sarvaśaḥ / sa vai dṛṣṭapado dhīraḥ (Uv.16.11c dhīro)

comments.comment: . Certainly a name like mahendrasene ( b2, a4, a5, a1, a3).

Certainly a new word ṣito*, like ṣiko. No verbal root known to me. Cf. ṣitaiṃ b2 ( propose to correct into pitaiṃ); possibly b5 ṣītai, but requires reading oniweṃ - on the other hand, the whole passage makes little sense anyhow: reading mistake? Cf. also ṣī a1 and b3 tai (not nai!)
On IDP, recto and verso are reversed.

ṣmareṃ ṣareṃ: Ogihara reads here ṣmareṃ ṣ(m)areṃ, saying that the m "may be covered by a displaced piece of paper" (). In my view, this cannot be correct, since there is simply no piece of paper there. More likely is a mistake of the scribe, who wrote ṣma...ṣa...ṣa instead of ṣma...ṣma...ṣa. On the other hand, Ogihara's interpretation of the passage is convincing.

comments.comment: The fragment is archaic because it shows ä for class. a (/ə́/) and ew for class. au: ñäṣträ a2; wäntärwa(sa) a7 kärttsewñe(sa) b5.

The fragments IOL Toch 809 and IOL Toch 1244 belong to the same leaf: IOL Toch 1244 a5 (the last line) is continued by IOL Toch 809 a5 (the first line), and IOL Toch 809 b3 (the last line) continues IOL Toch 1244 b3 (the first line). Since the precise wording of the Tocharian text in both instances is not known, it is not feasible to reconstruct an image or to count out the number of missing syllables, if any.
Uv.20.13d yo ’tivākyaṃ titīkṣati
Uv.20.14b saṃrambhahetoḥ sadṛśasya caiva

Uv.20.14d tām uttamāṃ kṣāntim ihāhur āryāḥ. We find ārya for regular āryāḥ, but note that the pausa visarga is not written in this manuscript: it lacks in a5 for mithaḥ (– • instead), in a7 for yuktaḥ (yukta • instead) and in b3 for punaḥ (n· • instead).
Uv.20.15b-c pariṣatsv atha vā mithaḥ / krodhābhibhūtaḥ puruṣaḥ

The reading of this line is particularly uncertain (and changed slightly compared to ), since in IOL Toch 1244 only the upper part of some akṣaras is visible, and in IOL Toch 809 only the lower. As I do not know how to restore the whole line, the number of missing syllables is uncertain; it is possible that the last e-vowel of IOL Toch 1244 belongs to (the first akṣara of) ṣemeske on IOL Toch 809.
Uv.20.16a satyaṃ vaden na ca krudhyed
Uv.20.16c sthānair ebhis tribhir yukto
Uv.20.17a-b śāntasya hi kutaḥ krodho dāntasya samajīvinaḥ
Uv.20.17d krodho nāsti prajānataḥ
traces of the c and the o of ścono can be seen, too.
Uv.20.18b-c yaḥ kruddhe krudhyate punaḥ | kruddheṣv akruddhamānas tu

On IOL Toch 809, a little piece from the recto is flipped over at the left. I do not know how to restore this line either, so the number of missing akṣaras, if any, is uncertain. In I had reconstructed a loc.sg. (ś)c(o)n(aine), which is not in accordance with the manuscript traces: what seems to be [c] (the line is going slightly up) suggests rather an all.sg. (ś)c(o)n(aiś)c(ä).
Uv.20.18d saṃgrāmaṃ durjayaṃ jayet
Uv.20.19b asādhuṃ sādhunā jayet
Uv.20.20a akruddhasya kutaḥ krodho, here apparently akrudha(sya).
